Posts.Title: Shampoo

Posts.Content: Dolina  Weep away and rant and shout as much as you like. This is a safe, caring and non judgemental place to do so. As you have already seen lots of lovely people ready to share their stories. And all willing to be as supportive as they can be in this virtual place. I suppose if there was one simple easy answer none of us would be here in the first place. This site and other good well known cancer websites are the places where you will get some answers but not necessarily the definitive one. Because you are a special individual and will be treated that way. Please avoid that mad man Dr Google - as I was rightly told by another Community Champ when I first posted. Some of the info on there is not reliable, up to date or necessarily true. Keep posting and keep sharing to ease that weepy pain. The Awake thread are up all hours you will find solace and friendship there in the night hours. I am a 'goes to sleep, then wakes up early to think it all over' type of person. Take care and be gentle with your self. If you can't share with friends or/and family. Share here 'You are not your thoughts. Love yourself like you would a best friend' Take care Leolady
Posts.Title: Can anyone help me please with lymph node question please.

Posts.Content: BaxiM  So sorry you find yourself here after what seems to be - no medical knowledge on my part - but a long and difficult few months. No, you are not a 'wuss' you have just experienced a lot of surgery, poking and prodding, diagnoses plans etc etc. If it hurts it hurts and no matter what scale of pain they give. If it hurts you then they should be able to see. My veins are none too good either and I will have a PICC line. There has to be ways of making this work for you, with little or no pain. But then I feel it is the role of the professionals to be guiding you and finding the best way to deliver your medication. If you think it would help; in the Ask an Expert section of this site, you can pose your question to a nurse. Her reply may take 48hrs but then it will be a medically based answer. link No doubt other people will come along and may have better experience/ knowledge than me Until that happens, do keep posting and make yourself the priority in your life for the duration of your treatment and recovery Take care and be gentle with yourself Leolady56
Posts.Title: Needles in feet

Posts.Content: Brads Look at this link on Information and Support  https://www.macmillan.org.uk/information-and-support/diagnosing/causes-and-risk-factors/pre-cancerous-conditions/breast-calcifications.html This could help but is not necessarily the answer But be pleased that your consultant is not accepting the first thing he sees. A core biopsy will give a clearer assessment and is one of the forms of evidence that is used to discount cancer or plan the next steps. With regards to the biopsy you get a local anaesthetic in the breast. Now some people sail through and others find it not too good. Really a needle in the boob not on the top of your what shall I do today list.  I chatted merrily away to the nurse throughout mine. It helped to be preoccupied. I think size of breast can make it more or less challenging If you need support and guidance everyone on this site has the skills and even the been there done it t-shirt Take each step as it comes - easy enough to say but not always easy to do. Share with someone close to you. And if possible take someone who knows you well along with you to the biopsy and the results appt. After both if at all possible go for a coffee or tea, cake or chat before returning to work or life  Hope your visit to this site is short and sweet. Take care and enjoy your weekend Leolady xx
Posts.Title: I had a ultrasound and mamogramme on wednesday. Want do sterotactic...

Posts.Content: Twinkle51 If like this Leolady you are very fair skinned I think you will find you will bruise easily and especially as the tissue in the breast can be quite soft. The lump will be your body surrounding the wound area in a fluid to protect it, a little like a lump forming after a bump on the shin say. My underarm lump was quite pronounced - well I thought so! The consultant allayed my fears telling me he had seen bigger. When I knew I had an issue was when the area became very red and inflamed, plus literally hot to the touch. Everyone on here told me off and sent me off to the doctors. For which I was very grateful. But as others have said - not least our very sensible Jammy - don't worry and post on here when worried or concerned. You are bound to get a sensible reply or a kick up the proverbial to get it fixed Hopefully you will now rest easy and enjoy the coming festivities. Take care Leolady xx

Posts.Content: Mandyw50 Also the schools may have links to other support mechanisms They may well have support groups within the school too Pastoral support groups in secondary schools can be very good And the schools knowing so they don't pressurise for homework, PE kit, trip money etc etc  Leolady56 - retired teacher
Posts.Title: Is there any respite care offered for children and young people who...

Posts.Content: Nicky No need for thanks because everyone on this site is on some sort of weird journey. One we didn’t book a ticket for either.  People on this site have traveled many paths to get here . I hate to ask but what type of cancer have you got? Or are they still deciding? DCIS or  a cancerous tumour . Equally how big? Gosh what invasive questions and ones you may struggle to answer.  But if you can answer these, those who have been on the same path as you might just have some answers  But one of the very best things you have done is find this site. I had DCIS 2 years ago and did it all by myself. This year I now have full on cancer but it was a small tumour. If I had logged on to this site 2 years ago I might have got the information I needed and not be here this  evening  If you feel you have the info and can explain do The one thing I have learnt is that every NHS Trust has a different approach, procedures and support. But here we all give 100%  Take care Leolady 61 and counting
Posts.Title: Treatment options

Posts.Content: Restory  To be honest ........ I had offers of plenty of help to come to each session with me but stuck to just my daughter (much older than yours) . Hubby drove me mad on the unit. But that I thought that part was doable alone. Though ...... cumulative affect could be an issue with the tiredness of it all so getting to the unit  may mean you need help I think if there are no friends  around and if you become rather poorly then having hubby that first session is not a bad idea,  also he can see the poop it brings and needs really to see that. For most people the first 1/2 days seems fine then when the drugs ease off the rest kicks in.  I guess being prepared for the what ifs? Is a good idea. If you are poorly what should your daughter do, who to call quickly etc. Friends (and not the ones you expect) will rally round when push comes to shove and try not to refuse the help Hope you have seen there is a monthly chemo thread where you can share all emotions, thoughts and final celebrations when it concludes. Gentle hugs, hoping you are lucky enough to get minimal SE's Leolady56
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Winky49 Yup you do sound good old fashioned fed up , other words are available . It’s that case of I’ve I have got it all organised and now another curved ball Think that person was either being a little unkind or very helpful. Mmmm wonder which one So, do you have an Occupational Health person or HR team you can talk to. Your working conditions affect your health therefore affect how you perform at work. I think that would be a good line of attack. Maybe you can evidence how you worked when under the stress and how you have been working with out it. And if you are a member of a union you can always seek their advice and if necessary their support. And don’t forget the helpline on here there are people here who can advise Tske care Wendy don’t let them get you down , you’ve beaten BC Leolady56

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Addison  Well a warm and sad welcome to a site we all never even knew existed. If we did we never ever thought this would be somewhere we needed to post. I am so pleased you have found this reputable site and have dodged the Dr Google less reputable and downright untrue ones.  It knocks you to the boundary and back, and you do start to look at all the little things; the what if I had; maybe too much x; maybe too little y; and why did I not see it coming. The reason being is cancer has not a discriminating bone in its' body. It picks on anyone . The biggest bully we will all ever meet. So ... stand up to the bleeping bast***. You define it and do not let it define you. This site is full of people who will support, guide and help you through the times ahead. They will not judge how you feel, which emotions you express or if you just want to hide under the duvet. But they will be here. Each step of the way you will find threads to help you conquer the next phase. I think what we all like to say is .... it is doable. Yes back when things were different, knowledge was different, treatment and procedures have moved forward. They continue to do so almost daily Until such time as others come along and post, do keep posting here or on other threads that may be of help Make you the priority in your life for now. Be a little (and some days a lot) selfish. The sooner you can mend the sooner you can start your new normal Gentle hugs and positive thoughts from someone still doing the treatment part. Leolady56
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer, having surgery Monday.

Posts.Content: A cosy and warm, if gentle, welcome to all of you whether you are starting or continuing your chemo this month. A slight change in title again, a suggestion from another champ that the word "thread" was less friendly and everyone on here is so friendly and supportive of one another. The chemo chat thread is a great place to help support and advise each other during your sessions. You can use the 'Save In My Favourites' button just to the right to put this discussion on your profile page for easier access. Lots of helpful tips for getting through chemo from those who've been there can be found clicking here: Chemo Tips If you found something helped you during chemotherapy, do reply to the blog and add it to the list. Link to the November Thread Wishing everyone minimal side effects, positive thoughts and hugs from Leolady56

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Molly The cancer that started in one place has a nasty habit of invading all our thoughts both good and bad. The moment we celebrate one thing we have a nagging doubt in our mind about the WTF iffs All I can suggest is you ask someone, ideally the consultant, to sit and explain everything clearly to you. I hope there is someone who can go with you to keep you on track. You've been so far and done so much. I , as you may know, have had 3 ops in 9 weeks. Yesterday I finally got to say to the main man tell me and tell me again: who what where and why. And he did.  So my story says go back ask ask ask and ask again. Your mental and emotional health will aid in your recovery. Just me really knowing has helped 24 hrs post op as I feel I can cope. Positive mind has helped Leolady

Posts.Title: Ex Partner demanding 50% Critical Illness Pay Out

Posts.Content: Emem So ..... glad this is being of help to you. Secondly...... nothing and repeat NOTHING around here is 'small bean', If it affects our emotional and mental well being then it is POOOOOOOP. And the triage chemo team are there to supply advice, guidance and support. They get bored if you don't call them. They are there for every little thing or big thing. CALL THEM. You also call a GP or 111 if your get a rash or a raised temp from the infection. Nip the little bleeper in the bud. NO exercises not a good plan.  I'm not a medic this is from all I have learnt from living the poop and supporting on here. And a big dose of common sense that new super power!!! I had a PICC line. Blooming Godsend. OK another procedure to got through and you may need to visit the hospital weekly for it to be flushed and cleaned, but in the big scheme of things that could be a plus. I am thinking a repeat of the last chemo is not on your cards. A lot of people also go for the porthcath earwig o tagging you for advice on this one. BUT ..... not all NHS trusts will supply them. For sure Oxford and Bucks do not. So........ get calling please. Get help please. And drop back in to share what next Gentle hugs  Leolady56 - a year on and all clear (it's doable hun)

I spoke to a pharmacist just recently and she agreed it was all the additional rubbish  that was added that caused the issue.  Maybe either ask onco team to state to GP. Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Mica There is a dedicated thread here for people going through chemo and at the start there are tips and advice I will put the link at the end. It is so challenging to know which side effects will hit each person and it is also about so many factors: the type of chemo, our age, what we have had surgery wise or not, as you said how we are generally now. My experience as with a weekly drug called Paclitaxol. I was hit hard the first week and the next 2 weekends were a wipe out. I did have the day after as high as a kite due to the steroids. But we are all so individual. You will even read of people who continued to work and look after the family. I decided that I would not use the cold cap  to save my hair- others have enjoyed success with that - but it was not for me. I went short, then shorter. Then by the 3rd one I took control and shaved it all off. I made the decision whilst I could. It was then scarves and wig. I have more hair now 2 months on. I did get my eyebrows semi-permanent make up and bought a serious kick ass red lippy to cheer me up. Try to avoid less reputable sites and Dr Google can be out dated I know others will come along with stories and advice. If you can look at the link and read but don't assume this will be what happens to mom. The site is a challenge at the moment as it is undergoing a big upgrade. LINK Mica in all of this don't forget to look after yourself, walk away if things get a little tough if only for a few minutes. Post here or in this group which is for CARERS . People will listen and reply. Cancer has a nasty way of invading all our lives and turning it upside down for a while. But so so many people survive and go on to lead new lives Gentle and positive hugs Leolady56

Posts.Content: Careermindedoptimist  Just read your reply to Luce and wanted to say - NO beating yourself up. If I had gone through radiotherapy back in 2015. Well let's not go there ............ An easier ride? Who knows?  And the whole individual aspect is so so true, which in a way should help us feel that for once we are not being treated as 'the person with cancer' but me with it. I hope you are finding this site as great source of information, support and guidance. Plus a safe place to share your feelings  Hope all goes well with your treatment too Gentle hugs and positive vibes to you Leolady56

Posts.Content: Tray46 One of your comments hit a nail on the head for me. Cancer being invisible .... that is so true. If you had a broken leg then people would have a different attitude towards you The main thing I read from your post is the need for you to talk. Maybe parking it here is of help enabling you to express what you can't elsewhere. Sad to say not all nurses (and to be fair people) make a connection with us during any life experience. And sad to say your has not, I must say i only ever called my team for physical issues. BUT ........ 0808 808 00 00 helpline may have a voice you can link to or they will suggest other local places you can seek help near you. Did you have a Maggie's centre at the hospital? They have many activities and chat groups too. Dr Google is not a good source of info too many outdated posts, so do avoid it all and stick to reputable sites Please seek help and cry in front of your friends it has been a traumatic time for you. Tears are soap for the soul. Sending you a gentle hug and some positive thoughts. Remember how much you have already been through and pat yourself on the back for that. In fact celebrate in some little way every new day you wake up and hug your loved ones . And maybe read some of the posts to your hubby,  Leolady56

Posts.Title: A moan if I may !

Posts.Content: mich78  A warm but very sad welcome that you had to come and find us. A club we would love to keep the numbers low and not for selfish reasons either I and everyone on here would love to say don't worry it will all be ok, but as we are not medically trained and we can not see you we can't do that. What we all can say is many women come here and many women leave here never ever going through breast cancer, they find a lump and the answer is simple and the treatment too. And 100% we hope that is the case for you But you are now in the hands of the professionals and if needed things will move quite quickly - sometimes not quick enough especially when waiting for results - but much faster than in past and treatment is so so different now. Be assured that should it be you need support it will be here waiting for you in a non judgemental way How to cope with the waiting. Please avoid Dr Google and stick to reputable sites if you must seek answers. Try to fill your days with as much as you can, if you have a family this wont be difficult, and above all breathe. Try not to over think it all or possibly set aside an hour a day to think about it all ...... some people swear by this as an approach Until then we are here  Leolady56

Posts.Title: Swelling after 8 days free lumpectomy

Posts.Content: @treacle321 Okay you are very very new to the site so I cannot tag you, Tag means you will get an email to say a reply has been posted This is a horrid time and one we didn't get a manual for. But pleased to say you have posted on one of the safest, most supportive sites  Just to say I have no medical knowledge but I do have BC - breast cancer I am going to deliver an opinion for your post Well done for the weight loss, gosh you must send us all the diet  Yup the tracker is done by a radiologist. It helps the surgeon to focus on the exact spot rather than dig around. Digging around not a good plan in soft tissue and your boob Results can take up to 2 weeks. I know you  are now thinking WTF. But there is a lot to do in the labs to grow and decide what is lurking in your boob. Each surgeon will have a plan they ask for, yours is going for the marker first in case he needs to operate Now ... no one on here can say what the outcome for you will be. We so wish we could. What we can all say is You have found a safe, caring and non judgemental place to be. You can post 24/7 and some one will reply I think not doing Dr Google is one of he best pieces of advice i can give. Because, it can be outdated, scarey and can be selling some sort of miracle cure So .... in between times. Well, try to fill your days, hug your loved ones, have some fun and post if you need more support on the thread you have created Take care. Time to be gentle with yourself and be your best friend Leolady56 I bet coz I am rubbish at typing others have come on to support you

Posts.Title: After Breast cancer treatment.Very helpful article by ? Psychologist...

Posts.Content: Welcome to October everyone – for many you have a light at the end of the tunnel. If you are having radiotherapy this month, this is the place to ask questions, get support and chat to others going through it at the same time. If driving daily don't forget to ask if they offer free parking, most do :). And keep lathering the lotions on your site. The Radiotherapy tips  thread contains all sorts of tips posted by breast group members to help you get through radiotherapy. My tips having just completed RT: drink plenty of water; use plenty of cream (Aveeno was my favourite one); rest when your body tells you to; accept help and befriend the RT Team. You can use this link to refer back to the September Radiotherapy Club.  You can use this link for far more extensive information info about Breast Radiotherapy. While this page covers any possible Side Effects From Radiotherapy treatment - Both at BCC website. Video of RT session. Leolady56 and all the Maccy team.

Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Lucy Don't scrub away at the boob be gentle and yes try E45 or Aveeno a good idea. I found the glue needed a gentle peel away BUT do not pull away unless Surgeon has seen the wound and has okayed it. I spent ages thinking the glue was the scare!! Numpty I was and surgeon genlty told me it was the glue. Well who knew. I coaxed it gently away but after I had my 2 week check up. The blue can take a good year to go and again don't scrub, breast tissue will be settling after the ops. Try cream on the rash give it a  few days but if no luck or if it gets hot/red/ inflamed or you feel as if you have a temp... than off to the GP you go. Good luck hope the sun is making your time of mending better Leolady56
Posts.Title: Dry skin/healing

Posts.Content: James UK  I have just discovered you had made a written reply to me and was unaware of that. To tag someone @ is put first then their tag name. As you type names will appear in a drop down bar and ensure you pick the correct one. There are many similar ones. Then the name will highlight in pale blue so you know they will get a message to know they have been tagged I was out learning how to be a better Champ on Monday and was fairly shattered as I needed to be a grown up learning, been 3 years since I last needed to do that. Now more to the point, it seems you got some good advice from others regarding all the diagnosis tools they use during the early days. I too had CT, Bone Scan, Biopsy and bloods. And automatically the brain goes into over drive. The better the picture they have, the more they know they can then plan the best approach to treatment. Do come back and say we will be waiting. And yes waiting is one of the worst parts of the whole sad process, but doing the going away and getting on with life whilst adding in a few fun things, is the very best possible thing to do.  Sending you positive thoughts take care and both be gentle with one another and yourselves Leolady56 aka Lindsay

Posts.Content: James UK  Whoops no it didn't think you left L no worries I am on here when I can to check everyone is being good to themselves As SueG said all good news I've had a bit of a trying time with my oncologist - not enough hours in the day to explain. So on our last visit my hubby had put his phone to record. I suggest you may need to ask of the consultant if that's ok. But we found it really useful. We could rehear the numbers etc and we could ask at the time what we wanted instead of note taking I hope I said ....... Avoid DR Google. Yes I am sure if you sift and prod enough you will find good answers. But it is often plain scary, out of date and attempting to sell miracle cures. Stick to the tried and tested sites for good up to date information. And keep posting as everyone on here is a source of up to date knowledge as we are bleeping living it!! Right the days will scoot by if you are working and you fill them with simple happy making things. Suddenly it will be 3rd April and you will have a treatment plan. Positive hugs to you both. We are here Leolady56

Posts.Title: A total mess

Posts.Content: Dotty25  You are in the right place. !00% support, advice and guidance is given by women (occasionally men) in a non judgemental way. This is where no matter what the time is - and I see you were awake at silly o'clock - you will find people to chat. The Gremlins -as I call them - have a nasty habit of keeping us all awake. There is a thread called Awake.... The whole waiting is a game none of us ever really get used to, but we learn to fill the days with as much as we can and posting on here. The whole cancer game does not come with a manual so when the smallest thing changes we quite rightly question it either rush to the GP or hope it will go away. NO inbetweens now. But I have always said go to the GP or call the BC Nurse. If it bugging you or keeping you awake then go. Because at this time our mental and emotional health need just as much care and attention. The whole BC is so different now. The diagnosis, The treatment. The meds to combat treatment or to keep it all at bay. It is a whole new world of survival of seeing families grow and being there. I have a grandson to hug and a daughter's wedding to plan. I AM NOT missing out on those. And you are not missing out on being with your little girl. Because ....... all the medics are going to do their very best to see you beat it and we will all be here to support and hug and cry with you and laugh with you. My surgeon told me 'I am in the business of saving lives and breasts'.  Right now then. It's time to have a joyous few days with that little girl of yours and all your loved ones. Stuff chocolate in and have a little bit of fun making great memories for you to look back on . Gentle hugs and keep posting  Leolady56
Posts.Title: A total mess

Posts.Content: Jessica70louise and Jacqueline The very best thing has happened that you have been persistent and kept getting medical advice Lumps and bumps can be a literal pain and mean nothing at all, but others that do not even give us a twinge can be the ones that cause the most issues. Sadly knowing the answers for you and your mom are not going to be found other than with the medics/ professionals.  There are many things that spring to mind about what could be happening, but without medical knowledge it would be wrong to suggest. But let's hope that it is a simple answer and a simple fix. As having survived so much already you and your mom do not need this. You don't mention the GP, do keep them informed as they can help to move things along too. Well mine has certainly been a help pestering people. I would say if a doctor/surgeon/consultant is being dismissive and unresponsive you can always ask for a 2nd opinion. Again the GP being on board would help Others may come along soon and give even better advice Until then be gentle with yourselves and try to fill your days with simple pleasures Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi again Snuggles and M20 Have you seen the walking thread. I can’t put a link on my iPad but will do so come the morning . Walking back to happiness  Months ago we were into anxious and struggled with extreme fatigue. So we started a walking thread. No need to say 10, 100 or 100000000000 steps. Just say you walked, if you can post a piccy even better. Again in the spirit of Mac M its non judgemental  I’ve met another person through this and when we can we gallop together  Okay I embarrassingly gallop It’s a Miranda thing. And she walks like a grown up  The point being get out , move , shift the wobbly bits.   My dear Mr Leo had  a high type 2 diabetes.... he cut down on carbs and I joined in. Success for him and me, now not saying this is the answer but there is I one for you out there Or start a new thread on here  Eating back to happiness But BC is not going to define us ok Leolady56  See you on the next thread snuggles
Posts.Title: Overeating while in the waiting game

Posts.Content: rubyrose  Hi Ruby I was in a similar position to you but nodes were clear. The biopsy showed the tumour in my breast was a grade 3 - naughty little critter cells unusual and a fast grower I named it Ian. That's a long story but being in education you have a lot of names you are not fond of Basically I needed 3 ops this last 9 weeks. And oh boy was I angry and went into meltdown when told about a 3rd op. But when I spoke to my consultant after I had almost demand a mastectomy, he told me clearly that he was in the business of conserving my breast and giving me the best most efficient route to good health. He was so cool. calm and collected with me.  The upshot is your consultant is going to do the very best he can too to give you the very best outcome he can with as little invasive surgery as he can.That may mean a mastectomy Then they will create a plan that will again move you towards good health. I read on one post how someone had thought 'Right I am taking a year's sabbatical to get well. Then I will have 20 or more years to live.' I think this way too now. Posting on here and reading other people with similar diagnosis is a good move. Maybe your hubby would benefit from doing the same or ringing the helpline. My hubby has gone into very helpful, pragmatic mode but I know he worries and I have seen the tears in his eyes when we go to appts. I started posting last Nov 2017 and now have lovely supportive caring friends all over the country. And I now have a new purpose as a Community Champion Sending positive thoughts and hugs to you both Keep posting and using the site, this is a non judgemental safe space Take care Leolady

Posts.Title: Life after breast cancer (posting for my mam)

Posts.Content: Jax68 No second lumps for me but a lot of DCIS that needed 3 ops to be booted out. Like you at the time I thought WT BLEEEEEEEP. But my surgeon was cool, calm and collected - unlike me who screeched at a registrar 'Well cut it off', when I heard I needed a 3rd op.  I was firmly told by the surgeon he was in the business of saving breasts and lives. So I am thinking your team will be doing the same..  I am here and have survived the poop of treatment. Just had a positive check up, but tell me that back at Christmas and I would have denied it could ever happen. Yes it could be poop and yes it is doable. We will ensure we can be of help through this for you Gentle hugs Leolady56

Posts.Title: Not a good day!

Posts.Content: Mandz1001  3 weeks for all your body has been through is still a small amount of time. Some people bounce back well good luck to them we all say. Others it is a long and difficult path back to full health. My time over Christmas was tortuous and I thought it would never ever end, but it did and some days I feel great. OK I didn't have all you  had but I did have 3 ops in a short while. So what I am saying is sit back, allow your body to end in its own time. Rest and sleep are good  Sorry Mac have not replied. When did you call them? Today? Days ago?  Have you called your BCN or the team of BCN;s? I am hardy surprised work is not on the cards and hopefully there are no outside pressures to go back. You must be your priority at the moment. Be a little bit selfish, do what your body wants and chat away on here. Share all those difficult emotions for people on here will understand more than you know. Please try your BCN Team or try Mac again. I will do what I can to help from afar about the no call back Gentle hugs lovely lady Leolady56

Posts.Title: Home after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: For some another gentle welcome to here and for others an equally gentle, caring welcome as you start chemo. The friendship and advice on this thread is second to none. You might bound your way through chemo like a Mad March Hare or limp your way like a wilting daffodil, but someone here will understand and be here with friendly and supportive words of advice. The chemo thread is a great place to help support and advise each other during your sessions. You can use the 'Save In My Favourites' button just to the right to put this discussion on your profile page for easier access. Lots of helpful tips for getting through chemo from those who've been there can be found clicking here: Chemo Tips If you found something helped you during chemotherapy, do reply to the blog and add it to the list. Link to the February Thread which will close in 4/5 days for posting. Wishing everyone minimal side effects, positive thoughts and hugs from Leolady56 and The Maccy Team

Posts.Content: ceecee152  Wow fantastic news about the clear mammograms it certainly gives the rest of us a big light at the end of the tunnel of treatment I have had chemo and lost my hair, plus on Letrozole so read this with interest. A friend who is a nurse and has gone through this poop of BC, recommended me to take sea kelp tablets to encourage hair growth. I have done that and yes it is helping. Whether it would stop the hair loss of Letrozole I  am not sure. But for a small pot from a health food H&Barrett, I thought it was worth a try. And as my daughter who is a nurse always tells me  'That tablet might just give you expensive pee, mom'........... such a pragmatist my daughter Sorry I cannot be of any more help And once again great to read of success stories Leolady56

Posts.Title: Thanking everybody

Posts.Content: concepta  This bleeping cancer so affects us all in different ways. My hubby comes to every appointment with me and chats to everyone. BUT will he talk to me about it. He is sat reading the news now and I bet if I started a conversation he too would go into 'ostrich mode'. Lots of mmm, yes and no. I feel they love us so much that facing what is an awful time for us is scaring them to bits. They must be worried that this will harm us more then they can control. I do think men like to pick up a hammer, a screwdriver or any tool so they can fix it. This is one thing they have no tools for at all. Now that's a worry for them. Plus it is all the emotional language that certain people do not have and have never needed to have. They are not practised in saying whatever is needed. My eldest daughter is the same , so please everyone reading this it is not necessarily a gender issue. Fear and worry of loved ones being ill strikes us all so differently. I do think if there is a male family member or good friend who you can talk to and who will then hold your hubby's hand that could help. NOW ...... I do think when your lovely hubby is faced with the reality of chemo and the side effects he will have no choice but to step up to the mark. If you are being ill from the side effects he can't ignore that.Maybe your lovely daughters need to say NO dad we can't help today you need to do it. He may need to go 'cold turkey' on helping you and he may not get it all correct or he may be forced to. By the way if my hubby asks me one more time if he should cancel the holiday we have booked in November I may just make the front of the newspapers and I don't photograph well. Tee hee No, lovely lady congratulations on 50yrs of married life and lots of hugs and positive thoughts for today I am not too sure if this has helped, but I am sure others will come along with other ideas. There are groups for him but it would strike me that pouring out his soul on here is not his thing Now you know ......... be gentle with yourself and look after you. God bless Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi Cant say that was an SE for me but did get the restless legs for whatever reason a while ago long before BC So.... pull toes up towards  body and point toes like a ballerina. Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: LiziX   A warm but sad hello to this amazing site I found it back in 10/17 and since then I have found friendship, knowledge, understanding and unconditional loving support. It is truly somewhere that you can share your worries and no noe says 'don't be silly' or 'buck your ideas up'. We say 'kick its ass' and 'swear away' Hopefully in finding Mac site you have avoided the less useful and plain out of date Dr Google. I suppose if you had endless hours - yup 3 children that is gonna happen - you may find good advice If you haven't already done so tell your children's schools. They may well have a great system for supporting and nurturing them during this difficult time Truly I have found people want to help. I have friends of all ages and everyone wants to help in any small way they can. This does mean being open and honest with them but .......... The cynic in me says they are glad to dodge the bullet we took and equally they just want to help you battle it too. The main thing you must try to do is put yourself first most days. You will need lots of time to mend physically, emotionally and mentally. You need to be your best friend in the coming days If there is a significant other half they may need the support from here too. But we can signpost you or them there as and when It is doable. It is treatable. We can all survive. But we must listen when our bodies ask us to rest, eat and etc etc. hard with 3 littlies but get that support network and get it working for you. Right off to get my hair cut short as I too start chemo next week Gentle hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56

Posts.Content: Anonymous49  Just wanted to say I too experienced that fact that though I was told my nodes would be checked whilst I was under during the 1st operation that did not happen as ............ it was past 4 pm and they had gone home!! I joke not. My surgeon actually put in a complaint and got me to sign it as well as him. Furious  ........... that's ok but unable to console yourself is a worry. I think your final paragraph is the one that speaks the most. A loss of a parent is a massive time for anyone. Even now 15 years later the smallest thing will bring my dad to mind and a song will have me in floods of tears. So, for you the whole situation is very very raw and now thrown into the mix the fact you are fighting BC and NHS poop/ rubbish systems. Well ...... Practically there are things you can do. Contact PALS and write down your frustrations at your treatment and they will deal with it. Maybe that will mean you can park that part of this. And I genuinely think you would benefit from some emotional support too. Maybe your GP is a good ear or can point you in the right direction; the 0808 number here is a source of support too; Maggie's Centres and Haven But keep posting here as you know people will come along with great support and suggestions Be gentle with yourself and make you a priority in your life for the coming days Gentle hugs Leolady56

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Kerra  There is no right or wrong way to do this. And pretty obviously your lovely mum has been coping with lots. I have 2 daughters. One is a nurse and copes really well sending me positive thoughts, daft pics and just fun things to my phone most days. I know she is saying I'm here for you mum. Even a little bracelet that has not left my arm since last October when the poop started. She has come with me to 2 appts. We love coffee and cake, and do that when we can. Even if it is a take away when days are difficult.. My other daughter (lives in France)sent me a small box of gifts; positive vibe cards, emergency choc (that didn't last long), a little book of happiness where I write about things that made me smile each day, a well known coffee shop card. But messages as well. Plus pics of my grandson and him always shouting 'nana hope your boob is better'.  You see it is the little things and the remembering the little things that matter. Goodnight text/message or a good morning one That's the plus side of mobile phones and social media Take care of yourself too and be gentle with yourself. Add something special into your day too. Little pleasure Leolady56

Posts.Content: Bluebell22 Obviously not what anyone wants to be told but as Londonlass has said better that they gather every scrap of knowledge together before they go in to operate. I think we all still underestimate how an operation can still have a massive effect on our health. So best they have all the ducks in a row RT as Lass said could be the next stage. And it’s another attack on those bleeping cancer cells. Its so hard when they take things away from us, it’s like taking a comfort blanket . This past year that has happened to me twice and though I’ve fully understood the whys and wherefores I’ve had good old nagging doubt. Take care Leolady56

Posts.Content: littleone31  My chemo was Paclitaxol My hair began to fall after the 2nd chemo. By 8-10 days after I was finding the stress of loss more annoying, bed full and shower tray full. I did not go for cold cap as I already struggled with headaches.  But I love wrapping the scarves and wear a wig when I need to to lift my spirits. I ordered pre made ones but did not like the so they went back. Take care Leolady56

Posts.Title: The Fear is starting to hit now

Posts.Content: PicaPica pop to your local pharmacy and ask to get your blood pressure checked too. For me a high bp can mean pressure headaches and chest pain. If once you have readings on 5/7 days you look on NHS BP check monitor you will be able to see if your BP is raised or OK. Don’t just accept one reading you need to look at an average Several meds can cause a change in your BP as do anxiety and stress Hope an answer is found Leolady56

Posts.Title: re refral for lumps

Posts.Content: Roundhouse1 These are some lovely response to your non judgemental and 100% love and care for your mom. Hope reading these it will give you the wherewithal to approach your mom. It was for me the fact I have a grandson that made me want to fight this BC bas****. And the fact my youngest had just got engaged. One important thing I am hoping is that the team around your mom are fully aware of all of this. And yes you may need to go behind her back to tell them. Emotional and mental health play just as big a role in getting well as does the physical treatment.  Like the lovely Ruby Rose I had hideous depression again work related. I lived in my PJ's and hardly left the house. Until my sister and youngest arrived to kick me up the proverbial. Not allowing me to wallow.Dragging me out and about. (Hubby was  working abroad). I think faced with the grand children and them primed to sit by her, hold her hand, telling her tales of the first weeks back at school. Tell them they are going to help Nana get better by doing this. They are her extra special medicine and all medicine needs to be taken in small doses, so we may not stay long. Children have massive resilience and just keep coming back for more. Just sometimes we have to be hard on our loved ones, tough love. I bet she used tough love on you before now. Read extracts from these and read survivor stories. There is a link if needed Take care lovely lady Leolady56

Posts.Title: A bit of good news

Posts.Content: Tc38  Life can be pretty unfair sometimes and sadly not always helped by the professionals we put our trust in. But you did all the right things and persisted with the GP. And though he wasn't the best in that situation he did eventually listen. Maybe there is another GP in your practice who may have a better manner that would restore you confidence in the profession As to what is happening in your breasts. I am not too sure anyone on this site can give the definitive answer - which is not really the best of help to you when all you want is a clear cut answer so you can plan and get on with your life. I do know fibroadenoma  are benign cysts and are hormone related. I am not a medical professional but know this; has my sister had many of them over her years. They always seemed to appear when her hormone levels were high or playing up eg periods , peri-menopause and menopause At the moment you need to trust the professionals and the good thing is the GP has now referred you  back  to all the people you met and trusted before. Until that appointment do be gentle with yourself and remember no Dr G - not always a great source of recent and unbiased information. Hopefully your next post will be 'guess what, good news' Leolady56

Posts.Title: Tamoxafin/chemo curls

Posts.Content: auntiesmirnoff33 Hi there and welcome if this is your first post.... sorry if you have been around a while and I've not noticed. Lucky you with the R1 and R2 creams as many GP's and oncos wont prescribe them as they are not cheap. I just used a well known search engine and came up with a whole list of where to get them from including Ama thingy site. I think what you or the GP needs to do is check with your pharmacy/ local chemist if they can source them for you. They may be reluctant. From what I have learnt either the |RT team hand them out or people buy them online Through my 20 zaps I used Aveeno and still do 7 months on. It worked really well and as a redhead with fair skin, I was pleased CLICK HERE for the monthly RT chat group and the opening page has some advice Good luck with the RT Leolady56

What I have been adding is : glucosamine sulphate; cod liver oil; Tai Chi and walking as much as I can. ( I am 62 BTW). There are many discussions regarding the joint pain from AI's and I know others will add their opinions and advice to mine. As I have been sat here for a while I will need to move as the joints stiffen up.When I wake each day, I wriggle and jiggle my fingers and toes, wrists and ankle so I don't stumble around for the first few minutes. Posts.Content: Hi Susie Firstly apologies as I can’t tag you or put in links as on my iPhone . Laptop updating Grrr But...... There is a designated monthly chemo thread for every month where you will find further help and advice The truly annoying thing with the SE’s are they will hit you in a different way to other people, so you may just sail through the whole thing; have a cumulative time of it or be hit like an express train from day 1. Not what you wanted to hear I know but honesty does help. Lots of people have issues with mouth sores and many swear by frozen lollies, ice cubes and frozen pineapple to overcome the issue. I found small amounts of food better than a meal then again I was on a different chemo than you.  Some people even use fasting at this time there was a thread discussing this recently too But one of the major thing that will be said to you by everyone is : Listen to what your body wants, needs and craves. Having cut back on carbs as my hubby is diabetic OMG I craved carbs during chemo. So I ate them. Ok I will now need to drop the weight but I felt good and my body felt good Hopefully others will post with more advice and good luck to you through this part of your treatment. Don’t let it beat you and don’t let it define you. Just make you the priority in your life for now Leolady56
Posts.Title: Mum has started chemo...

Posts.Content: Hi See you’ve skipped over to this site  Clear margins - from my knowledge - is all done in histology. Once the tumour has been taken they want to know that the area around it is clear. Now .... anywhere between 5mm and 10 mm clearance are expectations. My surgeon wanted 10mm hence 3 ops. Now each tumour may - repeat may - have its own histology. Just recently there was a post where tumours were very different. Treatment goes with the most challenging tumour. So .... radiotherapy and drugs could be the way forward  But and a big but. Don’t over think it any more than you already have. Read posts when you have the answers and try really hard not to guess the unguessable. Looks like you’ve been reading posts and projecting where you think this will end. Blimey we so like to be in control don’t we?? So hoping the chemo has done its job and shrunk the tumours so the next stage is an easier time One day at a time Hugs Leolady56

Posts.Content: Lacca Hi and welcome.... so at least you have found us. At least we understand. At least we are non judgemental. At least we have been there and done it, we are not sitting on some high horse. t least we wont say at least. NOW................... 1. Kill them with kindness. Yes you lovely people you are all so right. Lucky you haven't had it or at least I think you haven't got cancer ..... I mean who knows 2. Give them a full on meltdown. Embarrassing and they will no doubt go for the 'at least that will be the RT' and 'poor woman'. Or do they tut and give sideways sad looks, tippy head look. Had that one yet????? 3. Start your reply sentences with 'at least', see if they get the hint.' At least I have found a place where thousands of cancer people get it.' 4. Come on here and have a bleeping good rant. Feel free to drop some scorching words. Now 16-17 months on I get 'well you wouldn't know you've had cancer'. ME: 'No apart from when I was bald, the dent in my breast, trashed nails, and my hair growing back. Apart from all of the bleep I had, no YOU wouldn't'. They mean well and I think they are saying. You look amazing and sadly that is all they can manage as they are frightened too. Frightened about upsetting you and truly not knowing what the bleep to say.. Also they are so grateful that they dodged the bullet that is cancer. If this is truly getting to you emotionally and mentally then please do seek support from here, your GP, Maggie's Centres. As you can see I go for blunt humour with people.My coping mechanism Gentle hugs

Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Sun and RT. As promised ladies This was the reply I was given when I Asked the Expert: Patients undergoing radiotherapy should avoid the sun completely as the skin will be extremely sensitive and will burn.  Patients should also avoid using sun cream on the treated area during treatment as there may be ingredients in the sun cream that can irritate the skin.   This skin sensitivity lasts after radiotherapy has finished, particularly for the first 6-12 months after treatment, but is really lifelong.  Patients who have had radiotherapy in the past should always be aware of the sensitivity of the skin and be careful.  We would recommend a high factor sun block at all times when out in the sun, and wearing clothes than don't have a big weave in the fabric as this can let the sun in.  The skin where radiotherapy has been given will always burn quicker than other areas of the body, but it is still a gradual thing, not instant so you get little warnings like a tingling to the skin which should tell you that you need to come in out of the sun or put some more sun cream on.   British skin foundation Care in the sun Leolady56

Posts.Content: Welcome to July everyone – for many you have a light at the end of the tunnel. If you are having radiotherapy this month, this is the place to ask questions, get support and chat to others going through it at the same time. If driving daily don't forget to ask if they offer free parking, most do :). And keep lathering the lotions on your site. The Radiotherapy tips  thread contains all sorts of tips posted by breast group members to help you get through radiotherapy. My tips having just completed RT: drink plenty of water; use plenty of cream (Aveeno was my favourite one); rest when your body tells you to; accept help and befriend the RT Team. You can use this link to refer back to the June Radiotherapy Club.  You can use this link for far more extensive information info about Breast Radiotherapy. While this page covers any possible Side Effects From Radiotherapy treatment - Both at BCC website. Keep going lovely people: It’s one more step along the world you go. Leolady56 and Maccy Team

Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: juniruni I see you have received one lovely and supportive reply already The curved ball that is breast cancer is bad enough but then to get another one is just not fair. Sadly, cancer is not fair and doesn't discriminate either. And no matter what the press may say it can hit who ever and whenever it likes. Yes we can all 'could do better eating and exercising', but when you have been here as long as I seem to have been you learn that is a load of poop. There are so many ladies here diagnosed, being treated, going through chemo and radiotherapy (RT) and surviving. Yes there is now a very high % of women here years after heir initial diagnosis. Treatment NOT a walk in the park for some, hell for some and others who can get on with life and work as if nothing has happened. And there is no way of knowing which one we will be. We do blubbering wreck around here. Well I certainly have. We do rant. We do rave. We do WTF. And we do laughs. Honestly because some things we get asked you have to giggle about. For instance...... I am 62 got asked to pee in a pot. And when I asked for why. I was told in case I was pregnant. I mean miracles take a bit longer!!! DOH. Crying in the shower is useful, you can blame it on soap/shower gel in your eyes. Now time to call in a lot of favours (that will sort out the good friends and the Sunday Best friends). They can't do treatment for you but they can drive you to places; pick up the kids; cook a lasagne for you or clean the loo!! That should sort them all out. I am hoping you have or will mention this to the children's schools. Often they have amazing support mechanisms. As and when decisions for treatment have been made pop back here and we will all give great advice and virtual hands of friendship. Plus point you to where you need to go for help. Now breathe. Remember what this will all be for. And make you the priority in your life and sod it be a little bit selfish Gentle hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56

Posts.Title: Found lump under arm 5 months after double mastectomy and lymph node...

Posts.Content: @Aries18 You are very new to the site and firstly a warm but slightly sad welcome to the group. Of course you are going to be anxious, that is really how many people feel when they find strange changes to their bodies. And we all think bad thoughts too. Now I am going to suggest you do some very important things. 1. Get an appointment to see your doctor as soon as you can. Because they are the professionals. We cannot say even if we were medics. Don't be frightened they are there to help you 2. Leave Dr Google alone or any other website. They cannot see your body and are sometimes very old articles about all sorts of things 3. Tell someone who you trust and love.This is hard enough for older people to carry but for you so young you need a caring person with you. 4. You are very young and must remember your body is changing still. Think if there was something you did that might have hurt your body in this way. A sport, a dance move etc. Then you can tell your doctor 5. Now phone that doctor 6. And breath because this may not be where you need to be. But always be aware of your breasts and changes to them Are you phoning yet???? I hope so Your English is very good and I hope I have given the advice that will help you Gentle hugs across the miles Leolady56

Posts.Content: Mrs50 Knowing generally what for you is a 'normal temperature' using the thermometer you have is important.The big issue as far as I was told was over 38-38.5C Also ensuring that it is constant for a short while and not quickly rising. Unable to get your temperature down  by the usual methods of upping fluids and paracetamol etc, then seek help.Remember 111 and you Chemo Triage team can give good advice too Amazing how we need to suddenly understand our body in greater depth. Be gentle with yourself, there is no manual for this poop Leolady56

Posts.Title: The BC Paradox and a Thank you

Posts.Content: catlover53 Each and every step of the way we are faced with so many decisions and I can fully see why you feel the weight and anxiety of it all Whilst I have been one of the very fortunate ones and have escaped lymphodema I know how annoying, debilitating it can all be from ladies and friends on here. Your lymph system is important in that carries lymph fluids,nutrients and waste material between body tissues and the blood stream. Just being a devil's advocat here (and I have no medical knowledge) Is the removal of lymph nodes to stop further transfer of other less wanted cells around the body?? Maybe ask this question of your BCN. If I don't what then? Every day we walk out of our front door we play Russian Roulette. Every day of our lives we have been playing it. What we CANNOT do is  beat ourselves up when we make decisions and down the road we find it wasn't the best one. Here goes: My first handshake with BC was back in 2015. They found DCIS. They operated, cleared the breast and suggested RTherapy. I looked at the %. and the side effects and I said NO. So here I am 10 months down the road with DCIS and a 3mm tumour again (actually all gone as far as we know). But I made that decision in 2015 and I had to live with it and stop beating myself up. My onco tells me he could never ever say if RT then would have stopped this happening again. I feel sure others will come along and support you, share their stories and help you make the decision Until then gentle hugs Leolady56

Posts.Title: Waiting for surgery

Posts.Content: JCBadboob I see you have already got some good info and advice from Fonty55. I have just popped in to say a warm but weird welcome to a site we didn't know existed and never wanted to find But you have found here. And what you have found is a site filled with great people living this poop known as cancer. It is filled with non judgemental advice and support. All your questions will find answers and remember no question is wrong or silly, so ask away. And whilst I am on right or silly that also means emotions. Whatever they are then that is it. You wont get a manual with cancer which is difficult so here will help. One good thing is that everyone is treated as an individual through treatment and though we share many side effects (SE's) they can be slightly different. In saying this I suggest you don't Dr Google as you may frighten yourself by reading out of date material,Here all info is fresh off the press as it is mostly from those living the poop. Until you have a clear plan of treatment keep posting and answers, support and advice will be here Make you the priority in your life for now (difficult if you have a family I know) but necessary to make good progress physically, mentally and emotionally. And if you can accept practical help from people Leolady56
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with High Grade DCIS

Posts.Content: Bumping this up as no replies possibly as it is an unusual one Madagascar is that where you live?? Whatever way this is a very safe and non judgemental site where support, advice, guidance and hands of friendship are given Hoping someone is out there with an answer for you or can say 'Yes I have been there' Please if you can avoid that Dr Google, too much info to trawl through and some info outdated TNBC Group on here you could try re posting this comment Sending you gentle hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56
Posts.Title: Palb2

Posts.Content: WhatHappened  Thank you for this. I have always felt that knowledge is a powerful thing. Hence why I joined this site. My Onco-Gate issues were eased because of the knowledge of women and men on here, for which I am eternally grateful. So as you quite rightly say if 1-10 benefit from this then excellent news. I guess way back when discussions about Herceptin, Letrozole, Tamoxifen filled the threads too and questions were asked about their effacacy Keep waffling and keep ensuring we are educated Take care Leolady56
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with combined Radiotherapy given "Limited Approval" TARGIT...

Posts.Content: @A68 Oh you are very new  as I cannot tag you to reply to you I only wish that there was someone on here who could give you a definitive answer so that the coming days will pass by quickly. But sadly that has to be in the hands of the medical professionals. They do tend to send rather generic letters out, I guess they hope we will not go into a tail spin....... but actually we all do. Because we all want to know yesterday and take charge of whatever is wrong with us. If you do hear that it is cancer then you have arrived in the right place. And please whilst you are waiting avoid Dr Google - so much information that is outdated and plain wrong. Stick to reputable sites. On this site you will find people actually living diagnosis, living treatment and living survival. It is doable.  On this site you will find all kind of support and guidance all in a non judgemental way. No question to big or too small. No right or wrong emotion. But .... we are both jumping the proverbial gun. And everyone here is more than happy for no more women to join this club. So enjoy that holiday and fill your days with simple pleasures. Set aside time to think about it and look at the replies. but do not allow it to consume you as it may be a simple answer and fix I know others will be along soon with wise words and hands of friendship Until then take care and be gentle with yourself. Leolady56

Posts.Title: Strange red lump and rashes on breasts

Posts.Content: Pointer Not exactly  the same as you no. But I did enjoy 3 ops to get clear margins. And I met another lady who was in the same boat as me at op2.  My breast cancer surgeon informed me he was in the business of saving me and as much of my breast as he could. This was after I’d yelled at his registrar well cut the @@@@@ off then and I’d refused an op until I spoke to the consultant surgeon Several others have had this and I know they to will come along to share We all think operation and RT goodbye breast cancer. But the pathology says no Whatever happens they are there medically fighting your corner and we are here to give virtual hands of friendship and great advice.  Leolady56

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: @restory Hi and a warm but sad welcome to a caring, generous and non judgemental group of people who are living this poop. There is no manual but instead there are wonderful people who will supply great advice, support and guidance. Of which you have already had.The advice from Sugartc regarding talking to the school is vital. The notebook to is a brilliant idea. You might want to get one too - I have for all the appointments and what I want to ask but immediately forget as soon as a doc starts talking. Rabbit in the headlights. Whatever is ahead do one special thing for your self - Make you the priority for this time. If you are in the best place you can be physically, mentally and emotionally then others around you will not feel so much of the strain. Use here to express any and all feelings and emotions. None are silly, wrong or right. They just are part of the poop Be gentle with yourself Leolady56

Of course we are sorry that you needed to find us, particularly as you have enough on your health plat. But .... you are here and we are here to be as supportive, caring and non judgemental as we can be. Because:"We get it" I am going to post you again to a chat we have  every month about chemo. Posts.Content: Aspen Join the club in every sense. Lost count of how many times I write something for the ether to gobble it up. I now – when on laptop – write replies in Word then copy and paste. Then until I see it has posted I leave it on word. OCD or what? But lowers frustration levels. To help you could:- Contact the team on here they can and will give you one to one support. Or keep posting on here and others will send good advice. Have you written your profile and filled in everything you can or want to say? Start a new thread on here people will get back to you. There is a Rant thread someone started a while ago. Did a bit of retail therapy myself today new PJ’s having spent weeks in mine I am fed up of looking at them. Plus they feel wrong WhatHappened No one is watching. Or are they????? Today a shortish walk for me. Went into the local town and parked at the supermarket that has 2 free hours of parking. Walked there and back. Bit of retail essentials. Hot cross buns, tights, Pj s and chocolate hearts. Also called in on the MacMillan roadshow van to say hi. Leolady xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi All My Day: 1. chat with Gp at 10 am  2. Chat with onco triage - Herceptin effect 3. Ambulance called 4. Trip in ambulance to Wycombe  5. 5 hrs on heart/  triage ward 6. Hooked up to machines 7. Commode -   8. X ray 9. Plastic food yuk 10. Registrar “where are the results from ultrasound”. Not had one!!! He did a mini one 11. Pericarditis ....  Yup that’s what I said to GP at 10am . Had it 2 yrs ago pre this poop. Thought gawd I know what this is.  Hometime But ...... no meds as need to go back tomorrow for them. Pharmacy closed and doc wouldn’t give me a script to take elsewhere. Not sure why!!!  So didn’t do much walking today ladies. Try again soon Hugs Thank the lord for my sense of humour Leolady56

Posted by Lindylou49
24 Dec 2018 5:25 PM

How much can change in two years! I came out of hospital two years ago today and had no idea what would happen next.  Obviously wasn't listening when I was told,,,

I had visitors for Christmas Day and was sure I could do it all.  I did, but at the detriment to my recovery.  How foolish.

Since then, radiotherapy, new meds, coping with work when not really well enough, operation on my knee, specialist physio you all know the sort of rubbish we go through.

This Christmas, I have retired from work, finished all my treatments except Lymphoedema clinic, have my lovely No 2 Son over from the States for 3 weeks, and, thanks to all of your encouragement and humour I am 2 stone lighter and walking whenever and wherever I can!

I wish all of you a very Happy Christmas and a Peaceful and Healthy New Year.

Thank all of you lovely ladies just for being there.

Much love

Linda xx

Posts.Content: ash7 You would be hard pushed to find these over the counter in the UK, I assume for very good reasons. The efficacy of their ability to address beast cancer is a total unknown I expect . My next tale is not only to bring a wry smile to yours and others faces, but to question what we read. Early on in my diagnosis I read coffee is good to beat cancer. Drink more coffee. A few days later it was eat more mushrooms to fight off cancer. My hubby said “ well mushroom coffee it is then” Weirdly it does exist When I  hear and read these items my first thought is “ if that is simply the case, why aren’t all oncos prescribing melatonin?” Sorry it may sound cynical but ... as you say check with the oncology team and maybe you can tell me go buy some Leolady56 - expressing an opinion not fact

Posts.Content: moomy Yoga is definitely on the list of good things to do. And supermarket sweep as well Definitely need some good March or April weather for a walk. Lunch or coffee and cake also a must Managed 5km around 6,000 steps on my walk and ............ bumped into (not literally) a lovely young lady out walking a neighbour's dog. We chatted then she announce "Mrs P do you remember me as you taught me and my brother. " Oh flip I did and they were a lovely family. Not been on this walk since probably this time last year and I was amazed at the changes. I drive it occasionally but walking opens your eyes to so much more. Now in recovery. But best part was getting home to find Mr Leo had got stuck into the ironing. He gets a big smiley face today Hope those with snow are Ok. Hubby and I have loads planned for the next 5 days eeeekkkkk, snow go quickly please.  Leolady56

Posts.Content: Sooooo an amazing lunch with friends today. OMG a pistachio dessert. So go for a walk LL walk off those naughty calories I am off down the village main rd. 2 ladies in front of me. Could either of them be ‘Walking Back to  Happiness?’ No but the one is one the same path as I am. I met and spent a lovely 60 mins walk with a lady from the village. We put the world to rights and had a giggle. We learnt about one another and shared stories of the big cancer world. Me Leo said ‘OMG. You would talk to a blind and deaf man on a galloping horse’. Tee hee Blooming cold though. My cheeks are as pink as my fleecy i BRIGHT shocking pink. Bet that surprised you all simba4me Think my 60 mins I will share with you 30 each is that a deal? Then when I get to CT/RT you can share your walks with me. ShimmeringUnicorn I will do 60 for us to share tomorrow. Don’t leave us we need a unicorn on this site too. Violetsniff Big sis insisted I could jump the skipping rope tied between the 2 drain pipes. I couldn’t!! 53 years on and she in NOT forgiven. Interesting vista from the train. But no doubt you had a wee giggle mrsox Only will talk to you if the butty had brown HP sauce on it. Mr Leo and I had sausage and mash supper last night. LOTS of HP sauce, but a healthy swede mash. He is diabetic so we try to avoid carbs. Well he does. I sneak out for cake and bread with me pal Jacmatholmad Given up on the bras thing go for loose fitting tops and a strategically placed scarf. I mean who in their right mind is looking at my boobs! Keep on doing it! Walking is our route to new friendships, a good and healthy mind and body Take care Leolady

Posts.Content: Jacmatholmad  and moomy  I am a Rock Choir chick. Started over 5 years ago. It's good because I can dip in and out when I want. Plus there are online resources so I never need to miss learning a song. Words, harmony parts are there to download Tonight it will be: With or without you from U2. Been a real challenge as 6 part harmony in some places. Recap - Your the Voice. And finally 'Don't Leave me this way' another one in many part of harmony and lots of repeats. But I have been a model student and practised this afternoon. Can you see my halo. Or we sing that one as well. So ....... put it into a well known search engine and it will pop up. There is a well known social media page as well. Plus I have posted videos and I was in one. Possibly the Operation thread Jac. There are 3 in our area run by the same lovely lady -Katy. High Wycombe, Gerrards Cross and Beaconsfield Jac hope your daughter is feeling good after the op, hugs winging their way to her and you. Leolady56 PS moomy I am an upper soprano but feel after RT I may be a bass. But I will sing on. You know the Abba song 'Thank you for the music' I love the opening lines

Posts.Content: Bashed boobies, colds, IT issues blimey I turn my back for a few minutes and all hell breaks lose. Happybird cheers doll I am in the broiler category. My bones may just make a good stew ! I went through menopause apparently. Apparently my body has decided on a rerun. WE HAD SO MUCH FUN last time around. Apparently I am good at making oestrogen. Who knew???? Maybe I could bottle it Yesterday I had a big day out in the CITY. Not much to gallop about but lots of underground and even on and off the same train scenario. At a Champs meet up next to MI6. I had worn appropriate dark clothes, a scarf wrapped around my face. I watched SPOOKS. I knew what was expected of me. I thought I could pass as Judi Dench So back to walking for me again until I get hit by the chemo/ rads train which is looking like a definite. I will be as healthy as I can if someone could stop them all selling choccy and wine . I mean really how rude and wrong of them STILL without my phone so no pics But I am out and about with a lovely lady this Friday she can take pics Leolady56

Alright me bab Take care Leolady56

Posts.Content: Well. Welcome to this thread. You may be surprised why it is here or happy it is here. Then again: ‘You have got to be joking! Do you know what is wrong with me?’ may be your response. This all began on the Extreme Fatigue thread. On there several people wanted and needed inspiration/incentive to get out and walk. Many people see the benefits of it in their life and to help on this; mad journey, train ride, rollercoaster ride and other positively rude words journey called Breast Cancer. It is not a thread created to make anyone feel less than they do at present. It is not a thread that will set people against one another. Being competitive with yourself or a simple challenge to yourself is the point, but not a race against others is a key premis. The idea is that you can do any of these or none: Post when you have walked. Post how many minutes you walked for. Post how you felt before, during or after. Or not at all. Post pictures from your walk, but ones that do not point to where you live. Post inspirational quotes, thoughts or comments. A simple like of people’s efforts is fine. No need to write an essay unless you feel the need. On a safety note. Do tell friends, family or the thread when you leave and return safely. Be aware of your personal safety at all times.   Well here goes. Either it will grow and blossom, with lots of lovely people benefiting. Or I will have egg all over my face – not for the first time in my chequered life and career. Leolady – may be adding in the odd gallop to my walks. PS if you don't like us don't be cruel.

Posts.Content: ronstar OK so knowing you are safe is good. Knowing that the poop has hit the fan well.............. unconditional love is what we give our children. And not to have gone would have caused greater angst and maybe rift. Go stick on a big cheery smile. What would be more difficult is not knowing. And if future SIL is a total wazzcock when he meets the feisty future ma in law ........ well he may duck and run Enjoy and savour the time Me too WhatHappened this bleeping pericarditis has left me struggling. Made worse by the fact we have cancelled our trip to S Africa for November as insurance companies wanted to hit massively hard (I mean stupid money £880 for me for one trip and one company £1000) or not even insure as more didm't. As today is just one week since diagnosis, then being practical I need to accept it. And yes we checked out all the sites on the thread on here. Feel gutted for Mr Leo But ........ today a trip to Rickmansworth for a whole day of Indian cookery from scratch. Bloated and amazed, best description. We may never buy a take away again Hugs to all who did get out and to those who thought about it. Massive positive hug to you ronstar Tai Chi tomorrow a lot gentler Leolady56 Leolady56

Posts.Content: lesleyhelen  Firstly a massive woooooo hoooooo you. For all the changes you have made and for the perseverance this must have taken. Plus holding day a "couple of jobs". My hat is doffed. I've slipped off the radar due to a brush with chemo. And though we (Jac and I) had a lovely lunch today it was a good goat's cheese salad. I now try 1/2 days per week to ditch the meat and 1/2 have fish. Working on re - dropping the carbs. My short brush with chemo made me ravenous for carbs. White bread chip butties. OMG I craved them. Now being good. Blaming the steroids Well ....... hoping the inspiration spreads. 'One more step along the world I go. From the old things to the new, keep me travelling along with you.' Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Sunnyone All welcome here.. Whether it is 2 steps or 2,000 steps. A jog, a jiggle, a swim or a gallop. It helps to do something to keep those endorphins kicking in. Hope those results put a good smile back on your face. But if you are in need of further help pop onto any thread and chat away. There are so many groups as well that even I struggle to keep up with it. I am one of the Champs - a volunteer who has had BC and the one year clear, other Champs are living with cancer and support other groups. Keep posting  I'm now checking out a local aqua aerobics class to add into my Tai Chi and walking. Yesterday I managed a swim........ first time since Oct 2017 !!!! That was when the poop started. But I had forgotten how much I enjoy being in the water. So bye for now as I sign myself up Leolady56

But we had all the poop; we are still here; we support one another; we support new people and we have a giggle with our virtual friends Now stop beating yourself up or I will pop by to help you de-clutter (read the other post). Posts.Content: seaspirit44 so pleased you have found a Tai Chi class near to you. Today I have 2 hrs of sword play as I said yesterday. Blowing a gale here too. Bad luck about the hairdo. My hairdresser asks when I am next booked in.... then sagely says "That will mean rain then!" Last time it was snow! AnnJac  5yrs ago I climbed Snowdon with my youngest and the next day we went to Anglesea. It was sooooo lovely I felt like I had gone back to my childhood days. Simple, friendly and a gentle pace of life. Plus we found an amazing pub selling fab fish. I was pretty creaky after the climb and descent but still we achieved the climb Oh ladies who sing in proper choirs, I am so amazed at your knowledge. Me I just rock along to all sorts. We do have a local group of singers but I have found them all too snooty and up their own!!!!!!!!!!!! So I shall stick to Rock Choir Right think I will get blown to my Tai Chi class. Be gentle with yourselves One more step along the world I go Leolady56

Posts.Content: The weather outside is frightful But my dear it's so delightful So if you've no place to go Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow Glad I went out this morning I just mentioned to Violetsniff this Now sat watching the snow drift down. I am giggling a little at this as when I was in teaching and as a head I spent my days weather watching. Is it windy; if so hyper children. Is it too hot; if so lethargic children. Raining can't go out to play so lots of tussles and fights. Is it snowing do I open or shut the school, plus massively hyper children and staff worried sick about how they would get home. OH my now I just watch it happen from the warmth of my log fire AnnJac - we used to sing a little song called 'stick on a grin'. Keep sticking a grin on and eventually it will grow into a great big smile as you walk away from the hospital. There we go off to spread mayhem elsewhere Leolady56

Posts.Content: moomy Bring on the self cleaning house. Get that essay out and off you go to Dragon's Den. At the moment we have dust. DUST. AND DUST. AND EVEN MORE DUST. Sorry shouting above the drill as the plumber replaces central heating PIPES!!! Parked outside of town. Walked to hospital appt for an echocardiogram. And then walked back. OK via Costa for coffee and pain au raisin. Have to wait an hour after my morning tabs before I can eat and appt was 9.15. Well that is my excuse. So managed over 5,000 steps equalling 3km. Next stop Tai Chi. Wooo hooo another sword day and 2 hrs extra class on Saturday. Leolady56 PS saw nothing strange on my echo. Hubby said well no there wouldn't be!!!! Think he meant NO HEART (more drilling)
