Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: lindsaybubbles Well that’s one hell of a shitty curved ball. I’m sad to say hi but glad to see you have found us . Hopefully you did not get sucked into the DrGoogle rubbish that can be found out there Sorry I’m not able to offer a buddy hand but know that others will come along soon and say ‘Here’s a virtual hand of friendship.’ That’s what happened to me 11 months ago and it was much needed to know that there were others out there living the poop. They tugged me along the parallel universe with them. We added words to our medical vocabulary we never knew even existed in this world. We heard about meds, the best ways to ease side effects and how to kill those well meaning people around us with kindness.  And even now we say how the bleep did all that happen. Here is a safe place to scream, vent, giggle and holler. All emotions are the right ones. Did you see giggle in there. Yup ... at 62 being asked to pee in a pot in case I might be pregnant deserves a giggle. Hope the nurse who asked me has come now out of rehab!!! There are many threads here that can support you through this time. Many good professionals supplied by Mac too. No question too big or too small.  Until such time as others come by ... make you the priority in your life be a little and sometimes a lot selfish Leolady56 aka another Lindsay
Posts.Title: Looking for mastectomy buddy

Posts.Content: Hi hugle Lots of really sensible practical advice given by Toxo But as a mum with 2 daughters... one 29 and on 34. They send me simple messages, texts, cards , positive thoughts , pics and videos of my grandson. One comes with me to appointments as she lives in the UK and is a nurse. The other daughter lives in France hence the pics and grandson stuff. For me it is those simple things that help My youngest bought me a little bracelet it’s not been off my arm in 8 months . My eldest sent me a tiny book where I write a happy thought every night and I do it for her and for me.   You see , we all love a grand well intentioned gesture but we love more than anything the little things She can’t go to the coffee shop bring it to her. And hugs plus unconditional love like she did for you when you were little and poorly  You’ve got it . She’s got it. It’s doable  Lroladu56

Posts.Title: A very hard decision

Posts.Content: Roche Now that IS bleeping unfair of life.  We have a designated thread for RT July Group link for you. There it opens with advice and support, but it is also filled with women who are in the process which you may find very helpful Only 3 weeks ago and you are going back to work and adding in 20 sessions of RT.Plus the special and important visit to SA.. Right .......... as an ex head ......... get your GP to sign you off (unless there is an absolute need for you to go back). I always wanted my lovely team to be on tiptop especially for the end of term madness. RT is tiring and you cannot say it will take 1hr, 2hrs or 3 hrs out of your day. And you say you feel fatigue now. YOUR PRIORITY IS YOU.  Healing physically you may have. Healing emotionally and mentally, well would you be posting??? I am trying to be firm as I feel you need this at the moment. Hope you are not offended. Please take time, schools and work carry on with or without us. And if you feel pressurised by the school just ask for a referral to Occupational Health - they are usually amazing and make you their priority. But think tomorrow you phone the GP and school or email your manager today to say sorry but I am NOT really ready. Please post back on here or on RT thread I would like to know you have made a good decision Take care and be gentle with yourself Leolady56 PS spent 3 years in SA and back there for Nov.
Posts.Title: Brest cancer returned in other breast

Posts.Content: Wow That was a welcome to the weekend for you and your family. But the very best is you have found this site. It took me 2 years and a second diagnosis to find it. But it has been my saviour for so many reasons  I know you will get lots of positive posts from people who are kind caring and non judgemental. You will get lots of positive suggestions and help alongside of hugs  Now back to basics. Are you fully aware of the diagnosis . Grade it is 3. Adding more info can help . Your age. Post or pre menopausal. It’s amazing how everything you are makes a difference. And it’s amazing how things such as a great family, great friends, a positive attitude can also make a difference to where you will be in the years to come  Everyone is allowed to be in bits. But it is you living it all. So please put yourself first. I have a sneaking suspicion that’s not you! Please be gentle with yourself  Please post when you can and when you feel emotionally and mentally strong enough to. Also close family members can do the same on here lots of threads to follow  For now take time to step back and breathe  Believe me you can do it . Just look at everyone on here doing it. Posts.Content: Info19 No question is silly or too big or too small. But some are challenging for people like myself and many others here living with and surviving cancer. Your questions really need a professional opinion and so  1. You could call the helpline on 0808 808 00 00 where you will receive great advice and have someone who can explain where to look/ go for answers ( if they are answerable ) 2. In the Ask an Expert tab on here you can pose your questions to a nurse but be aware you may need to wait for a reply . Many of the Exoerts and all the Champs are volunteers.  3 Atrend meeting with the oncologist with your mom ( if she allows this) and ask questions of the professionals there There are threads on here regarding chemo and RT, but it can be a little overwhelming to read at the start. We have a Secondary Group too. Liver cancer now will be the primary cancer to attack Maybe others will have further advice, but do make that call to the helpline Take care Leolady56
Posts.Title: Relationship between cancer spread, stage and treatment options

Posts.Content: 232pookie I have not seen you post before. So if this is your first visit a weird but full on warm welcome.  The aches and pains you can certainly attribute to Letrozole. For some, like me, they have eased as the months have gone on. For others it is a slow build up. But more than anything I feel you would be wise to seek medical advice from your GP or send to your onco team. They can always adjust your Letrozole or change it to another AI. Others may have answers but do get an appointment if nothing but to allay the gremlins of fear and worry Leolady56
Posts.Title: memory and speech

Posts.Content: Roundhouse1 I was on Paclitaxol for just 3 out of 12 sessions. For me it was highs for 2 days due to steroids, low for 2 days then back to me again. I did one session of a high temp but a visit to A&E sorted that out. Yes I lost my hair after session 2. I also have Herceptin. I found that very challenging when mixed with chemo. Headaches being the worst side effect of all. But I am now heading for number 10. Aches and pains in hips and joints can be a big issue. Stiff hands and feet if she doesn't move enough. I take glucosamine sulphate with chronditon and Loratadine too. All of these you can get over the counter. Staying as mobile as you can for Herceptin is my best advice. Yoga, swimming, walking and Tai Chi (the latter my fav). I am 62 so no spring chicken Herceptin is a massive game changer for HER2 women. I heard this said many times. So I am putting up with th SE's Remember Chemo Thread the opening page has advice and support. I am sure others will be along soon with other good advice Leolady56

Posts.Content: Nicole279 I see both Ruby Rose and Violetsniff have posted and passed on their experiences. So, you can see this is a safe and non judgemental site where we can freely and openly share what we want to. No one judges or says it is right or wrong, as strangely there is no manual for this poop. But here there is tons of advice from women living and surviving cancer. Notice that last word as upwards of 90%+ women (and men) GO ON TO SURVIVE CANCER. YES not every day is easy, yes we have days and times when we get pushed rudely back. But every day there is here.  0808 808 00 00 is the number where you can find support if you need to hear a frinedly voice. You might want to look for a Maggie's Centre they offer all sorts of support Some units have Maccy centres too. Worth a look at too. Once you have a treatment plan we can signpost you to other threads where you will gain further support. Until then be a little selfish and make you the priority in your life.  Leolady56

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)

Posts.Content: Daisies Hi and sorry that though you have had one battle and won, you are now battling the emotional side of BC I have just written to someone else starting out that actually I think how any cancer affects us physically, emotionally and mentally. What happens is we get 'fixed' physically by a medical team and then ........................................................................  One good things is you are seeking  therapy and as someone who has had counselling in the past, I would say well done as it helped me no end. There are Moving on Courses too in many local hospitals. There is the helpline here 0808 808 00 00 who can suggest where these are happening local to you or other support groups There are maggie's where support and advice can be found I use a meditation app almost daily to help me rest and sleep. I go to a relaxation class. Have reflexology. Tai Chi. All I find amazing to help that mind and emotional part. Plus add in walking too.  try hard not to let this define you. You have been through so much Oh and if you are tearful CRY.  Now time to get some good cognitive behaviour therapy or something like this. To pat yourself on the back for surviving BC, for reaching out ( a brave move) and for loving yourself enough to seek help Leolady56

Posts.Content: youngatheart Hi and so pleased you've hit 50% success with a pink boob. NOW ...... I am on Letrozole and pleased because I know it is protecting my body from a repeat BC. And sadly we do tend to moan about things on here but that's part of the reason for Maccy. To share, to shed and to shout. Look realistically at actually how many women are posting to decry Letrozole. Is that it, is that all.  NO. Millions are out there popping the tablet and living life. Maccy can be a little like Trip advisor (gawd bet I lose my Champ badge for that comparison). You get 2 ends of the spectrum is what I mean. A fab hotel and a crap hotel and the same hotel.  Being a devil's advocate here...... you don't take it and BC returns. How will you feel?? I am now 7 months on Letrozole and ... yes it is not wonderful but the alternative does not sit well with me.  My perspective and feel free to tell me where to get off. And yes I am retired, so managing SE's I can stop the world for a day or two. But I refused RT back in 2015 after DCIS and I am back here!! I've tried hard to be reasonable about that decision but it does niggle. Nagging doubt. I don't like it. There will be other ideas I know but ..... sharing mine Hugs and onwards for the last 50%. Might be a hot coals time Leolady56

Posts.Content: Sash70  Every little decision we are forced to make is so challenging, I guess here can be a really helpful place for people to tell you: it's ok we all feel the  same, this worked for me, this didn't work for me. In 2015 after lots of advice and discussions I didn't go with RT but ..... would I change my mind. NO. That was the info I had then and I had 2 good years. Take control of the losing hair scenario. You decide to wear what you want, cold cap, scarves or wig or combination I first had a shorter cut than usual then shorter with the hair. When my hair started to fall I got very upset. Then one day I said 'SOD IT'. Clippers came out and I stood in the shower and it all went byeeeeeeeee. Hubby tidied it up sat in the garden making daft remarks like 'Doing anything special this evening, madam?' Daft bugger If you put cold cap into the search bar you'll get a whole list of threads and discussions about it. It wasn't for me. I don't do extremes of heat and I'd be well P******* off if it didn't work. Sadly there will be a constant footfall on this site. So always someone here to say 'me too'. And no fancy hashtag to that!! Gentle hugs and positive thoughts to you Listen to your body she's known you the longest Leolady56

Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: @lucy-B A sad smile but a warm welcome to the Mac site. It is so difficult this journey you are on, there is no easy path or mad dash to get you there quicker I am sorry to say. But you are now in the hands of the professionals and if they are in anyway concerned or worried they will move quickly. It might not seem it to you but they will. Finding a lump could mean many things but we naturally jump to the conclusion that it is the worst possible scenario - cancer. Yet some people post on here only to find it isn't. I am pleased you found this site to post one and hope you avoid sites that are not reliable and do not focus on cancer or are just plain scary as well as out of date. There is a lot of very good info on this site about what to expect when you go for your appointment. Also there are many people who who reply to you post offering good advice and support. This site is full of caring people who will supply you with a range of things; hugs, positive comments, daft pics to make you laugh (yup we do that too). It is a place where you can express yourself and express every emotion you might be feeling, because there is no one right or wrong emotion on this path. I sincerely hope you have a close friend, loved one or family member to support you. If not we will all be here whatever the time of day to cheer you on or cheer you up Now you need to start giving your self time to express your emotions, be gentle with yourself and treat yourself like you would your child if they were ill.  Until the appointment keep posting and stay safe Hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56

Posts.Content: Pooch2 This is the group Gay was talking about Carers Just a few thoughts from me though. Typical how people crawl out of the woodwork with all of the questions but none of the answers, as it seems her brothers and sisters suddenly have. Have you thought about the impact on your children if you do have mom in your home? Could this be a further stress. I realise 100% you have missed them. But is it a good idea? Will you need to put a room aside for her? Is there equipment going to be needed to ease her pain and help with moving her or seeing to her personal needs? Maybe these answers are on the Carers thread as they will know from experience. Is there no way her GP or hospital team could find a place in a hospice/ nursing home near you? This is probably the best solution in my eyes. Everyone can visit as much or as little as they want. As you are breaking point then seek help for you too. GP or here are good. I hope you do find the answer for your mom. And that is the way to put it to her family. Best solution for her Take care Leolady56
Posts.Title: Mum's Cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome to November everyone – for many you have a light at the end of the tunnel. If you are having radiotherapy this month, this is the place to ask questions, get support and chat to others going through it at the same time. If driving daily don't forget to ask if they offer free parking, most do :). And keep lathering the lotions on your site. The Radiotherapy tips  thread contains all sorts of tips posted by breast group members to help you get through radiotherapy. My tips having just completed RT: drink plenty of water; use plenty of cream and for several weeks after (Aveeno was my favourite one); rest when your body tells you to; accept help and befriend the RT Team. You can use this link to refer back to the October Radiotherapy Club.  You can use this link for far more extensive information info about Breast Radiotherapy. While this page covers any possible Side Effects From Radiotherapy treatment - Both at BCC website. Video Leolady56

Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: Anonymous49 Good morning from a dreary Bucks For me Aveeno was more than enough to lather on. Many trusts and GPs do not offer R1 and R2 as they are quite costly. Some people would say better than Aveeno and others not. The Aloe Vera cooled in the fridge was needed. As were the Actiform gel pads which the RT unit gave me. Again these gel pads aren't supplied by all trusts but can be bought off that well known Ama***** website. Now I found these the best ever, instantly removing residual heat. Lots of ladies just stick to their usual creams and some are even told to avoid deodorant especially if the armpit area is being zapped too. Yup keep taking the tablets .... as they say.  And drink plenty of water I finished 4 months ago ...... OMG where did that time go ........ but every day after my shower I moisturise as I find it gets itchy if I don't. Hope your journey is not too long and don't forget to see about free parking Nearly there Leolady56
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: OCRKate Use the creams especially Aveeno as many times a day as you can. I mentioned some gel pads as well.If the RT team don't have them you can get them online Actiform gel pads. They remove the immediate heat with no damage to the skin.  kathleen37 no medical background but I would avoid the cling film as it can hold the heat in. But feel free to check  elsewhere. There is an ask an expert Radiographer but 3/4 day wait for a reply, so maybe calling your BC nurse or the RT team. And here I am 5 months on and still apply Aveeno or it itches like made. Not an attractive look digging in my bra to scratch at my boob Leolady56

Posts.Title: Fear of reoccurrence due to fatigue levels :(

Posts.Content: Carolrob  My first Paclitaxol was Thursday and by Saturday I did have a cracking headache. I do have BP -blood pressure issues on the high side - so I called the Triage helpline I had been given. They encouraged me to drink more, have 2 paracetamol every 6 hrs, adding in ibuprofen but no more than 3 in 24 hrs. Obviously painkillers will effect the stomach but for a the relief of a headache you may want to do that. But....... calling your triage people and remembering to mention this when you next see your chemo nurse is very important. It may be an SE of your chemo or even the stress you were feeling making itself apparent. Take care, be gentle with yourself and hoping the next chemo treats you better Don't forget there is a designated chemo thread others may have advice Leolady56

Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Good morning from a soggy town sat in a caravan Hope you don't mind me popping on to add my knowledge to the group. Though at least one of you will have heard from me before. I needed 3 x WLE's to remove a tiny tumour (2mm), and DCIS. The surgeon was in the job of saving my breast and saving my life whilst maintaining clear margins . That is basically what he said to me. I am now happy this happened though totally confused and basically very worried at the time. And very oh woe is me. There are very clear guidelines and should be adhered to. If in doubt 'shout' up and ask . Hopefully you have a good BC Nurse who you could ask or go for a 2nd opinion. I have needed to do so due to a less than competent oncologist. It happens. But at the end of the day it is your body, your decision Take care and be gentle with yourselves in the coming months. Be your best friend each and every day Leolady56

Posts.Content: Swolish  The need to suppress oestrogen is well known to help. As far as my reading has been - and not my medical knowledge - oestrogen can adhere to the cancer cells. Mac link to a page of info. Another snippet of information gleaned from this site is that; different makes/ brands of tablets can have different SE (side effects) and some women swear by specific brands whilst for others they are worse.  As Fenouillard has suggested trial and error may need to be the first path for you. On a similar note I tried 4 brands of a medication before I got it right. But now for 3 yrs all is well with no SE's But keep asking and questioning Take care Leolady56

Posts.Title: FEC first one done

Posts.Content: Dear All If you've experienced any technical problems in the last week - or more - could you please report it here to ensure a better service. When you report it: * Tell them what happened * How often it has happened * How it makes you feel personally * How it affects your use of the site * Finally how it affects your view of Macmillan. And every time there's a technical issue that affects you in any way, please use the same form to report it and all of the above. I don't know about you, but I think the site needs a bit more TLC and attention from the tech team to sort it out and bring it up-to-date. And the more feedback they get on the issues, and from a wide variety of people, the more likely they are to fix it and sort it. Thanks in advance, and fingers crossed everything runs more smoothly ASAP! Leolady56

Posts.Title: GREAT TIMING......

Posts.Content: Sizzles My paclitaxol was cut seriously short due to a bad reaction to it. I got 3 out of 12. My onco said that's really good we should have done some damage to the cancer. He was afraid that the damage Pac could do permanently was more of a worry than keep going. And like Ruby Rose I had my Herceptin cut short to 9 out of 18, just last week tbh. And I am so pleased as I spent yesterday being assessed for an issue with my heart (pericarditis) Now .......... oncos are highly professional trained people and are doing all of this to protect you. You know in your heart that is the case I am sure. But like me I guess you think "but chemo is my safety blanket for it not recurring". Well in Sept I had my one year mammo and I am all clear. NO FFFFFFF CANCER to be found. Good hey.  So believe in them and above all believe in your decisions. I hope this is not too scary or pushy. I mean it all with a good (if poorly ) heart Take care Leolady56

Posts.Content: Veliz Most of us I would say. Some more than others due to skin tone,age etc Many ladies use Arnica and Arnica tablets. As a red head I do a great line in colourful bruises. In fact my most painful days after surgery were when the bruising started to appear, There has been a lot of shuffling around in your body so bruising is part of the process.Poking and prodding etc If though, the area becomes red and inflamed and hot to the touch do seek medical advice ASAP  I totally abandoned tight fitting clothes after my node removal, especially my bras as they all seem to sit in the wrong place Take care. Allow yourself time to mend and be gentle with yourself  Leolady56 x

Frankies_Ducky  Here goes from me for a little lesson in uploading pics.This is from my PC any other machine not a clue 1. Have your pics in a folder on your pc 2, The fifth little screen on the right on this tool bar, Click on that 3. Then you will get an insert/edit media screen 4. Click on Browse and open your folder of pics 5. Click on OPEN to upload in your folder's bar 6. Ideally cut down the dimensions to 300 by 300 or less (mac site not good with big pics) 7. Hit green insert button and the pic should appear that you chose. 8. Pray 9. Curse 10. Try again Sorry but the site often has blips so don't worry if it all goes pear shaped look forward to seeing your pics. Weeblemum is very techy.she might have a better instructions. Posts.Title: Thanks for support and some good news!

Posts.Content: sazzat  ABSOLUTELY you post here. And as and when your sister feels the need to she must. Bleeping BC is no friend to anyone and has a hideous habit of picking on people, just like the class bully. You will get amazing support on this site for many reasons; kind and generous people; people living with BC; families supporting people with BC; brilliant support and advice and a place where everyone can come to cry, rant, rave and laugh. YUP the last one happens often because of the daft things that happen to us along the way. There are specific threads for families Carers Only And a specific thread for people undergoing chemo for BC Chemo Group there you and your sister will find great advice and support as and when needed I am sure you will have spoken to the children's schools as they may have excellent pastoral support systems in place to be there for the children. I'm hoping that you have found this site the best for supplying support and knowledge, there are other reputable ones. BUT ..... dear Dr G is known for some seriously iffy sites, bad advice, old advice and purely wrong advice. So do keep to the reputable ones or be very wary of the rest. So, others will pop long soon with great advice and support and I don't want to overload you as I am sure the medical professionals have done that already. Until then positive thoughts and gentle hugs to you all. Leolady56
Posts.Title: New here and supporting my sister with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Maggie-Gaudigirl mine was tiny and needed 3 ops to kick it out. 3mm look at that on a ruler !! Miniscule. Mine had a lot of DCIS pals You see what the truth of the matter is in this area a size can matter but also so so many other factors. The pathology from a biopsy will tell a different story. And that’s what defines the cancer and not us No you are not alone 10 months ago I thought I was . Then I found here  And there has not been one time that I have been alone. Sad face really . But instead I have this gang of friends out in the virtual world who know . They just support in a non judgemental way. I can share the weirdest of emotions and they come right back at me with  yes that’s how I feel You need to do something that women, mothers , wives etc etc we do not find easy ..... Make you the priority in your life. In doing so you will mend physically, mentally and emotionally quicker Leolafy56

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy done

Posts.Content: Roche Hi I don't think i have seen you on the site before. So a warm but sad welcome to the site.  I too had 20 sessions. We do have a specific thread which I will put the link for you but ..... My top tips: 1. drink lots of fluids, try to avoid coffee or drinks that will dehydrate 2. Use the cream on the area 3/4 times per day, but not to close to when you have RT (I expect you have been told that) 3. accept support to drive you to and from the session, especially at the end . RT is a slow burner and tends to hit you near the end and after. 4. as soon as you notice any major changes tell the RT team there are plenty of meds out there to help 5. Ask if the unit use Actiform Cool pads or look them up on Amazon. They were a blessing for me. They took the heat out of the area quickly Good luck with it all RT Thread Link Leolady56

Posts.Content: Undergroundbarbie  Looks like I am going to say exactly the same as everyone else. Nerve endings, surgery etc etc Just to say if the breast does become red, inflamed or hot to the touch, skin looks very different to the norm then that is the time to seek professional help. But considering how long ago your op was you may have dodged that I hope you have found the site helpful. It is somewhere you can come and go as you please. Where you will find lots of good advice, support and plenty of good people. All of this in a kind,caring and non judgmental way Take care and be gentle with yourself as you mend. Leolady

Posts.Content: Kelly38 A warm welcome to this safe and incredibly caring site. Here everyone 'gets it' and are there to hold out hands of friendship. At times we even manage a good giggle. Hopefully you have spoken to the school so they too can be of support at this difficult time. I have learnt that children are amazingly resilient and accepting as they know no different (38 yrs in primary education and a nana) My grandson wanted a scarf like nana, so my daughter wrapped one on his head and added bright red lipstick. I decided bright red lipstick for chemo and radiotherapy (RT). I loved the pic and it made me smile on those crappy days Galligirl gave some lovely warm and positive thoughts. I liked my wig so much I am thinking of growing my hair to that style. I lost my hair 2/3 chemos in at the end of May and.......... now have a full head of curly hair. BUT ....... I have hair. So no fears on that point it comes back and you can have a new you look for ages afterwards. I am a glass full lady. I shall put the link CLICK HERE for the chemo chat Leolady56

Posts.Content: Cuppatime  Like many have said definitely the blue Aveeno for me too. And as you have time now start putting it on morning and night as it then gets to be a habit. Up your water intake too. 2-3 litres if you can. Only one day I didn't and boy did I feel the side effects of not. And plenty of cream to rest of body too, has a habit of drying out your skin. I've been lucky to be given gel pads to put on each evening which are amazing.I wear one at night to remove the heat. Actiform Cool. If your hospital not good try your GP. If you can add in a little bit of exercise and practise lying with arms above head in a relaxed way. Although it can be minutes it can be 15 or more if they are imaging. Not sure if your hospital offers weekend appts. Mine does and I took them makes it all a LOT quicker, no worries as all machines are up and working and staff want to get home for some of their Sunday. Didn't even get time to sit down today and was whisked in It is so so doable in comparison to what else we have all experienced. Gentle hugs help you through this Leolady56

Be your best friend this evening and do what she would tell you to do Leolady56

Posts.Title: effects....

Posts.Content: yellowdaffodil  Well a warm welcome to this thread then and come July there will be a new thread and sadly no doubt more people to share this treatment part with. 10 sessions of RT for me , so halfway. I've really had only 2 days where I felt wiped out. One being yesterday, so an early bed . But apart from a one hour journey there and a one hour journey back, plus some waiting time I have managed to walk a little. Apart from the other day when I managed 10km. I've started to do things like park further away from the RT unit (not too difficult with parking in an Oxford hospital!!!) Plus if you can you'll probably wait up to 3/4 weeks before RT starts so get moving now but gently does it. Also prepare the breast area if you can with a good non perfumed cream. I , and lots of others, swear by Aveeno. Do it 2/3 times per day and cover a good area spreading around the site. Mine is a right breast issue so I cover all of my chest, down to my tummy and around the back with cream. RT people gave me a pat on the back for that.  100% drink plenty of water. I think I was feeling rough yesterday as I had not taken enough on board and forgot to take a bottle with me. Plus I was rushing out trying to miss the traffic, so was lazy and did not stop to buy a bottle. Grr idiot. So plenty of fluids. At RT unit I was given some gel slabs called Actiform Cool. AMAZING. Pop one on and the heat is gone. Best thing in all this poop so far Well hoping all goes well for you and congrats for surviving the poop that is chemo. This next part will be so much easier Leolady56

Posts.Content: Georgette Any change in our breasts at any age needs to be looked at 100%.  Changes can be subtle as skin puckering, discharges or at the top   end of the scale feeling lumps.  But we know our bodies best and asking a GP is the best way forward From my last 6 months on this site I have learnt it is either something or nothing  I am sure we would all like to know it was nothing. It could be something totally different such as a trapped nerve or the onset of arthritis if she is of an age where this can happen 55 possibly is. Do tell her better safe than .... And yes maybe you have a heightened awareness of cancer but we all do too Take care. Be gentle with yourself and hope your pathway to a new normal is a gentle one Leolady56

Posts.Title: Enforced break in chemo worry

Posts.Content: SarahSS123 Well lovely lady a warm but a very sad welcome if you need to join this club. We are trying to keep it very exclusive but cancer has other ideas. Notice I have said 'if', the results will determine the outcome. What you need to know is that if it is breast cancer, the world of medicine is a very different place day to day than many years ago. And what was a head in hands scenario back several years ago is now not so true for more and more people. There are so many targeted treatments, all being made as easy as is humanly possible for us all to manage.  2mm is very small indeed, have you looked at a ruler to see. So they have caught it very early which is fantastic news. My tumour was 3mm. Once the know the type of cancer it is from pathology reports they will chose the best course of treatment if needed. You will have the opportunity to agree or not. Or take time to decide. The anxiety and fear are to be totally expected you have a lovely little one to love and care for, so why would you not feel this way. In the coming weeks of waiting you may experience a whole range of emotions and not one of them is right or wrong, it just is. On here you will find a band of non judgemental people who have just been diagnosed; are having treatment and ones who are on the other side. They will pop on and give you amazing support, guidance and virtual hands of friendship One big cry from everyone will be avoid other sites that are not reputable. Dr Google does throw up some outdated information and some quite scary I am hoping you have a good group of family and friends to deliver all the support they can. There are Groups here for partners, family and friends too if they need help understanding you and the possible cancer. As the support network around you cannot actually battle cancer 'if' that what it is then allow them to help you in whatever way they can and also tell them you may ask them to 'back off' if it all gets too much. when you have answers we will be here to point you in the right direction of any further support you need Until then make you the priority in your life for now Gentle hugs  Leolady56 - who has just about finished her 10 month battle/argument/war with breast cancer.

I can cry at Love Actually ever time I see it / other crap films too. But to cry about this poop mmmm. It’s the little things that get me I do upbeat then crash bang wallop for 2/3 hrs Dust myself off kick myself in the butt and get on with it Hope BF gets the shopping correctly placed and if he does he can have another star If he gets 5 he can go to the Heafs office for a sweetie!! Posts.Title: SNB (for DCIS) - jane304's story

Posts.Content: Thurg  Lovely lady a few days after my ops!!! Look at my profile wont bore you. A bath would have been the highlight of my day! Then 3 hrs sleep to get over it Please be gentle with your self. Look after your inner child. If this was you as a child everything would be done for you, you would be fed, cuddled and watered regularly. If there is a someone to do that then allow them to. If not gently take your time to look after you. But above all keep posting on this site where you are allowed to rant,rave, scream and cry in equal measures. Posts.Title: Not 'lined up' No RT today - anyone else have this?

Posts.Content: 966504 A warm welcome to the site though sorry that your mum is faced with BC and faced with this decision. I must admit having been on this site for many months now and as a volunteer Champ, the dilemma and the question has been discussed many a time. That is in no way to make light of the situation for you but to say "Hell yes many people have faced this challenging decision too." So no doubt others will come by and share their thoughts . If the consultant has recommended chemo they are not doing this lightly. they will have looked at all the variables and will have met with the multi disciplinary team (MDT) to discuss your mum's case. That will be their perspective and at the end of the day it is your mum's choice.  I chose not to have RT (radiotherapy) back in 2015 and I found myself back here in 2017 with more to deal with. Because of my decision in 2015 I took whatever they have wanted to throw at me. I stopped beating myself up about the decision in 2015 and stop using negative language about it too. And that will be something for your mum to consider. IF ( and no one has a crystal ball) cancer came back would she be angry/upset/annoyed with herself? Or will she say "that was then and this is now".  Will she constantly question the efficacy of her decision or will she be fine with it.  Sadly STATs are not actual people who can supply considered advice. 1% is small as you say, but ..... I am not too sure if I have helped but in sharing - as do here - maybe it will add to her decision making process Whatever her decision be aware that we will be here and we can signpost you to groups for chemo/ RT or AI (hormone treatment) support chats Be gentle with yourself and please do note that there are groups to support you too, should you feel the need of them Leolady56 - 1 year on and clear

Posts.Content: Mazda19 Another gentle and warm welcome to here Whilst some people work on through chemo others struggle and need lots of help. Then there are the vast majority of people who fall between those 2 extremes. And sadly no test will tell you which category your lovely mum will fall into. But as NiceCuppa has said (and she is in the middle of it all) we do have a thread. The opening page has advice and the rest is filled with chats and more advice as well as support from those going through it all. Knowing which chemo she will have can help us suggest possible side effects (SE's) as chemo comes in all sorts of cocktails. Now to be honest I never knew that until I came to here and experienced chemo myself. Aha both you and Nicecuppa were up at "silly o'clock". The gremlins of fear and worry and doubt have a nasty habit of calling in at those times.  Now rest assured everyone here will do all they can to be of support. The oncology/ chemo team around your mum will be the same. She will get a card giving her an out of hours service to call if worried. CALL IT for any reason you or she are worried, they are there to prevent your mum feeling too ill Right click here to get you to the chemo chat LINK the opening page has info Be gentle with yourselves these coming weeks and months. Posts.Title: Possible DCIS waiting for pathology report

Posts.Content: RoseKen1 It is all really overwhelming lots of terms, words and weird phrases plus the weird thoughts going through our heads. If you are here on the site there will be plenty of sound advice from people who have been there and done it, all in a non judgemental way. Hands of friendship will be held out at all times of the day and night. So no need to be facing this one alone. People to explain those terms and words I am an HER2 person too. Which has meant Herceptin injections and Letrozole, not too much fun but doable and as I always say 'I'm not keen on the alternatives'!! You probably have DCIS as I did and sometimes it is so widespread they need to get it all, they did with me which took 3 ops. Now I have a perky small boob that points upwards and a saggy old one pointing down. But at 62 I am still here and to be honest who is looking at MY boobs We all sincerely hope you come back to the thread you have created and post how things are going. Maybe in the future when you are well enough you can join us all in a meet up, which we do fairly often. So we can share the times together and finally give real hugs Until then pop back here. Post how you are feeling etc etc. All emotions accepted on this path (I hate journey sounds like a bad TV programme) Hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56

Posts.Content: LucyMc Sad smile from me that you and more over your mom needs to be here. Posts.Title: Weekly Taxol

Posts.Content: Cham  Poppy and Whathappened have both given you great advice. I am 6 months after 3 lumpectomies! And even now I can feel the odd twinge and yelp type pain as something settles back into place. Trouble being is we all have different pain thresholds dependent on what we have experienced before. Above all the mention of heat, redness and excessive swelling are game changers and you really MUST seek medical advice. It is more than likely an infection and a dose of antibiotics is the answer. I had one mid operation 2-3. I soon got the benefits of the meds. But remember your BCnurse is still there for you should you want a reassuring chat. That's their job Take care and go gently. Remember all the advice about lifting etc and try your exercises, but stop if they really ache Leolady56

Posts.Title: Mastectomy discomfort and Scars

Posts.Content: PollyMac  This seems absolutely not acceptable. It is bad enough that we battle physical, emotional and mental issues without a team who seem to care less have added to you. I feel 100% certain the hospital you attended and the surgeon you had  will have a formal complaints system. I feel sure you need to get in touch with them Are you in the UK? I am assuming so. In the NHS most (repeat most) people have to wait 2 maybe 3 weeks.Even then everyone gets very concerned, worried and stressed This wont explain attitude  is not acceptable you are entitled to the information. You should be getting letters both to you and your GP. Have you asked your GP? They should know. I found the following online: The first step is the hospital. Each private hospital has a Chief Executive Officer, Executive Director or Hospital Director. He/she is responsible for everything that goes on in the hospital.  Each private hospital and private hospital group has a complaints procedure If you need some further support with how this affecting you emotionally, the 0808 number on every page is great. So wishing you a better pathway through this Please keep posting on this safe and non judgemental site Take care Leolady56

Posts.Title: Mastectomy with reconstruction and breast reduction

Posts.Content: RumCat Welcome to the group we just don't seem to be able to keep exclusive! Cancer has other opinions on that But a warm welcome I saw you've posted elsewhere too and hoping that you realise you have found a safe and unconditional place of support, advice and virtual hands of caring friendship. Gentle hugs get thrown in too for those days when nothing else will do.Please do avoid Dr Google and keep to reputable sites Being in denial is common. I am one year on and still think 'Did all that just happen to me?'. The range of emotions will be wide and varied, and all WTF! That biopsy will be the deciding element to give the medics a plan of action. Of course they could be mistaken but looking at was has been said to you I would suggest they have something in mind. Obviously I am not a medic,on here we are people living and surviving cancer. There is an expert tab and the helpline to call, for professional advice. The holiday is a question you will need to chat to the medical team about. Can you carry on and go with this nagging at your emotions and mental health? (I am being devil's advocate here). Or is recharging your batteries before you face the treatment needed?  There will be others popping by to add in their experiences too. So until 3rd, keep posting and support will come. But above all make you a big priority in your life Leolady56
Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Top trumping Ronstar on this one But first of all what a total wazak that lady was. But on the - I’m being thoughtful thread - she needed to offload and genuinely thought she was being empathetic I have spent this evening in the local celebrating Burns Night . People hugging, avoiding, looking sympathetic and ignoring. Their experiences of cancer define their responses as donours luckily in a good way we would all hope So back to bath bombs.,,. I worked in education. One year I had a lovely package of items that included what for some pieces in the pretty bag was chocolate . I learnt when I sunk my teeth into one Christmas pudding ...,,,,.  Dramatic pause Drum roll Was a bath bomb!!! I can still taste it now 6 yrs on My daughters are still giggling . They cruelly watched as I sunk my teeth into it. Didn’t you know Ma!!!! Well there we go hope that lightened the mood. Take care and please avoid any bath bomb that says chocolate Leolady

Posts.Content: Hi Sara, I don't find myself with the same diagnosis as you have. But I do find myself often with the same feelings as you have. I think these feelings will go with every single group on this website. No matter which cancer you are battling with or whether it is you or a carer. On the plus side you have posted and you will get many great pieces of advice. I was in teaching until retirement and I used to tell staff to bring back a 'golden nugget' from any training they went on. If you read some of the threads on this site you will find many many golden nuggets to help you. And if you don't; this is an excellent place to lose or find 'the plot., No one is judgemental here and everyone is a great listener. Read on Good luck and take care. And do remember asking for help makes everyone feel like they are achieving something towards your recovery. Leolady aka Lindsay now post op 24hrs and known to gallop in a Miranda style to surgery (hope that made you giggle)

Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Princesa8  I do not have your diagnosis and as yet I am unaware of how CT or RT will effect me as part of my treatment. I get to hear that information next week. But what I do want to say to you is this: When we were diagnosed no one gave us a handbook that said 'This is how you will feel. This is how to deal with it. Oh and this is what you should have done.' If they had, none of us would be here and there would be no need for this site. But we are all here and we are all doing it, living it in our way. But what we have all found is a safe, friendly, kind and non judgemental site where we can share our feelings.  Do not be ashamed of yourself for how you feel. If you can recognise those feelings, give them some space to exist and then move on. I post some days, erase it then write something I would like to hear instead. But by scribbling it down I feel better. There is a place on this site called The Room - where you can do just that. Or post on this thread and someone will come along and help. Hopefully you have found the dedicated thread for those experiencing CT . Link here Please give yourself time to mend and be gentle with yourself. Give yourself a big hug like you would your best friend or a loved one. Take care Leolady

Posts.Title: Finally ready !

Posts.Content: Cycling girl So sad that you have found yourself in the club we are trying to keep exclusive but that git Breast cancer decides otherwise. Glad you have found here as there are many people going through what you are and they will be supportive and give you great advice. It is not fair that you are a fit person and yet cancer has come to call. That doesn’t particularly help our emotional or mental response to it. But as you will see cancer hits everyone no discrimination from cancer Chemo has no plan, map or manual. Sad to say. Many people get on with life, work, bring up the kids and others don’t . We all only wish there was a magic formula to say which one we will be so at least we can prepare for it. So help ..... look down the threads and you will see there is a specific group/ thread for chemo. I would put a link but on my phone. Laptop gone into meltdown I had a gentle brush with chemo. I allowed myself the days to mend when I felt like poop. Then I shook it off and tried to do all the usual things. And I accepted help. People can’t fight the cancer but they can ease the stress and give help. Just tell them if I say no thanks I mean NO. Others will be along to give support Until then make you the priority in your life and be a little selfish or a lot!! Leolady56
Posts.Title: How to deal with chemo explosion

Posts.Content: Devon Dumpling Here's an official hi from all at Maccy and so sorry to see you needed to find us. Be assured this is a safe, non judgemental site filled with great support and advice I see you have received some super support and advice already I did have my eyebrows done! But my beautician uses semi permanent make up approach not microblading. Many others have had it done and were very happy. BUT ...... get it done sooner rather than later. The reason being infection. And not whilst undergoing chemo for the same reason. During chemo the fewer bugs we attract the better. Many people have a good time with chemo and others have every available crap side effect (SE). We never know until we start when and if it all kicks off.  LINK we have a thread each month for the chemo time. of treatment You will find the first page has many great tips and is filled with people holding out a hand of friendship during this challenging time Hope all this helps Do keep posting. Share all the crappity crap crap, the emotions, the tears and fears, the laughter too. At 62 being asked to pee in a pot to see if I was pregnant I mean REALLY. Take care and make you the priority in your life enabling you to mend well  (had to return as typo..... it said men well. Gawd no need for that . Tee hee) Leolady56

Posts.Title: Over the halfway mark of my first journey

Posts.Content: Veliz  I have had 2 sessions of Paclitaxol. First one a bit of an issue due to a temp and high BP. But that is really me responding in this way and my onco was slightly surprised by both reactions. The second one, which I have on Thursdays, I sort of lost the weekend and a 'I am not feeling too well/ achy way/ headaches'. Thursday and Fridays are good probably thanks to the steroids. But thanks to the steroids not too much sleep - felt buzzy.  Third one this week - small BLEEP up on the part of ward last week, miscommunication - so shall report back.  Everyone has said it is the gentlest of chemos but is a slow creeping one, so you can be hit harder as the week's progress. And having chosen not to go with the cold cap - my BP gives me enough crappy headaches - I am losing my hair.  Well the sun is in the sky. So lather on the lotion and enjoy a chemo free day. Hope those struggling with the SE's get a gentle one. Take care Leolady56

Posts.Content: Dixsey Pixie. Sort of read between the lines tbh, having been there and done it. I’m not au fait with your cancer - thank the Lord I just kept to my brand- but your BCN May have got it right. And I assume the surgeon knew his stuff. Plus an MDT who discussed it all.  I’m thinking your ‘imagined consequences’, as you eloquently describe it all, is just another fun side effect of the poop that is cancer. The emotional and mental SE of cancer, well tbh one of them . What ifs seem to come by the cart load no matter where you are in this poop. No matter how many years past the finishing line I’ m on my phone and can’t put a link but there is a good article by Peter Harvey about life after cancer. You could see if you could find it or I’ll pop by tomorrow with a link . I took several goes to read it, I need to be in the correct head space to absorb it all. But it gave me some hope once I’d read it that I was not losing the plot or alone. This site also gives me strength and support  There has been a change in how some surgeons and oncologists use the Predict tool and after 16 months on here I see it mentioned less and less. I think it is considered a blunt tool these days.  Right apologies for any weird typos. Do keep writing and parking your worries here. There’s always a someone around to be supportive Take care and be gentle with yourself Leolady56 aka Lindsay PS keep popping by as we have meet ups often and chat away with people who “get it”

Posts.Title: Lobular breast cancer, ER and Her2 Pos

Posts.Content: Pat22  Welcome, you have certainly come to the right place for advice and support. Lots of people experiencing breast cancer and though it seems like one title, it is in fact many diagnosis and many ways of treating it dependent on so many factors. I too needed not 2 but 3 operations from Nov to Jan to get clear margins. It is distressing to think for whatever reason they did not get everything the first time around, but Lavendergirl has given you the reasoning behind it.  When I was very distressed at the 3rd operation I demanded to speak to my consultant. He told me very calmly and reassuringly that he was in the business of saving my breast and me. That 2nd and 3rd operation meant I knew what to expect, how I would feel physically and emotionally, how it would all mend and what I could or couldn't do as I was mending. A lady I met during my 2nd operation is now nearing the end of radiotherapy. I am just a few weeks behind but I know when I start the next course of treatment I will be in a good place both mentally and physically, because the professionals made the right decisions at the time. When or if you or your relative return to the site there are lots of conversations regarding Radiotherapy, recovery etc etc. There is also a Carers site should you feel the need. When the time comes you can be signposted to the support. Hope all goes well for you both Fill their days with positive things until the next op. Take care and be gentle with yourselves Leolady56
Posts.Title: Relative's Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Pat22  Pleasure. Yes it is difficult enough if you are in the same room and hearing the same thing as the patient. But several hundred miles away is even more of a challenge. I would say that choosing well known websites such as this one and breast cancer one is best for gaining information. Many sites on other search engines are NOT as reliable nor updated or have anyone checking their credibility There is the number for MacMillan that your relative can contact during the day if she needs further support and maybe if she is techy savvy she can join on one of the threads. 0808 808 00 00 is the number Do keep posting on this thread you have created. There will be someone with the support, advice and guidance you all need.Plus there are the Experts who can give better professional medically based advice The Experts  link Take care - hope you escaped to a sunny place Leolady56
Posts.Title: Relative's Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Dixsey Hi and a warm welcome to the world of BC and Maccy.  NOW .......... I am assuming you were expecting chemo and are shocked because this is now not on the cards? Or are you preparing for what may happen when you see the consultant next? I am not a medic, just someone who has been there with BC. I am pretty damn sure HER2 + tends to be attacked with chemo after surgery and more than likely Herceptin. They will not give Herceptin as a general rule without chemo. Plus an AI - Tamoxifen, Letrozole etc for 5-10 years after LINK click here for info on HER2+. on the site STOP PRESS. I just read your profile so please ignore some of this. Apologies, as not everyone fills their profiles  in, if I seemed a little vague. WELL........  I am surprised because at 62 and HER2+++ I was a definite candidate for chemo and Herceptin. For various reasons I didn't go the whole 9 yards with them both, but felt I had enough of a fair crack at them. And Oct 2018 pronounced clear after 1 year mammogram. ( I have completed my profile so read away) Have you had a one year mammogram yet? That could definitely calm fears and worries, mine did. (OK for another year) Take care and be gentle with yourself. I no longer beat myself up for refusing RT back in 2015 after my first brush with BC. Leolady56

Posts.Content: Oh so so lovely ladies  My time for sharing my journey has come to an abrupt end. Funny I have celebrated and shed tears. My 3rd Paclitaxol left me looking like a squashed tomato and with BP that could set a the Richter scale off.  I was met by my onco today who said 'Enough'. I am allowed Herceptin and have the joys of finding out if Letrosole will also be a good plan. It was such a weird day 6 hrs of fun packed NHS I some how didn't know that I needed to be in the unit for 2 hrs after my second Herceptin Well add that to you list if you are on it Then suddenly onco wants me there by 13.30 for a chat. And all change And tonight I get sick sick sick after yesterday's 3rd chemo Well I have got off lightly as you lovely women will be living it as I just crash from the SE's As a champ - of what I will leave you all to decide - I will pop back on Next step 3/4 weeks time RT. Might see you all there God bless to you all. Stay safe. Love your heart Leolady56 - oh I got a new wig!!!! And my grandson rocking a scarf to support Nan Poo OK not allowed

Posts.Content: Chuckles123  Ditto what everyone else has said. But do make sure that the Ibuprofen and Paracetamol are managed well ( when ill before BC  I made a school girl error, made me worse). The fluids is essential especially as it could be quite a warm day. BUT .... as I am queen of the high blood pressure. Cracking headaches are part of that and nothing can be done to get rid of that, apart from BP meds. If you have a BP machine or access to one then check it out. Or get it done tomorrow asap. Just a thought. Some pharmacies have them as well. Avoid coffee or caffeinated ones as they do clear fluids from your body. But above all seek help from the triage people  Gentle hugs across the miles Leolady56

Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Sue JH  I'm off the Paclitaxol journey see masses of previous posts and all my weird responses. I managed 3 but onco then stopped the train for me. Mixed emotions there I too had insect bites etc that went itchy and raw. I tried Eumovate which I had for a previous rash response (after surgery) that did not work so now I have an antibiotic cream, Fusidic which is slowly hitting the spots (so to speak). Just thought I would mention this to you as trouble with a steroid cream is it can over a length of time breakdown the skin's layers. So if all does not clear up maybe ask for an antibiotic cream. Just a thought. My 3 Pac definitely gave me: headaches, joint aches, nose bleeds, hair loss and dodgy tummy both ways, with some cramping tummy pains. I would say that these lasted no more then 2/3 days. Made sure drank water so hopefully I avoided cystitis.SE's wiped out my weekend but ...... retirement means every day is a Sunday. Pac is a bit of a slow burner with SE's creeping slowly up, but is considered a gentle form of chemo Hope you continue to tolerate Pac and that the SE's are treated - there are plenty of meds out there to battle the poop Hugs to you all Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi Lottie Looks like we have followed a similar path and I know we have shared posts before I’m 61 and bleeping bugger I too get scared  I get scared because I had a ridiculous reaction to Paclitaxol so 3 doses and stopped by the onco  But I’ve been ok on Herceptin and  fine on  Letrozole ( I am whispering this and have all fingers and toes tightly crossed) This evening having enjoyed 3 days of normality and possibly too much hilarity , I am now tucked up in bed watching the sunset and listening to my favourite go to music So ..., I got less of the chemo attack than you did but still feel pooped at times I’ve had to triple my Ramipril 2.5 to 7.5 that made me both angry and scared . I’d worked hard to get my BP sorted and on just 2.5 mg. Niecthis damned BC has put me back  My onco has kept me on Herceptin even though I did finish chemo. For which I am so grateful. I’ve heard that less than 40% heart function is an issue so crack on with 50% Fingers crossed that tiny spot is a blip Hope sharing this is not seen as ‘oh woe is me’ but that I understand and feel the same as you do Gentle hugs from Bucks Leolady56

Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Hello there Welcome to the site. One you probably didn’t know existed and certainly one you never thought you would visit. How I so wish that someone on this site,including me, could give you the definitive answer. Then you could breathe a big sigh of relief and nod off into dreamland. Sadly that is not what I can do and that’s so NOT what you wanted to read. On this site everyone  has cancer or signs of cancer in the breast but that is where it begins and ends. Some people didn’t have a clue. Some people like you found lumps. Some just felt unwell. Or their breast had changed. Mine was hello again at my yearly mammogram  The best thing is that you have been referred to a specialist who will be able to test in many different ways to see what this lump is. That might be manual, mammogram, ultrasound biopsy or the lot. But what they will do is everything they can to find the answer. When you feel you can you could search on this site for diagnosis. The second best thing you have done is to come here to a reputable site, where facts are given. Where there are experts to ask. Where there are lots of people experiencing the same worries as you and have a list of questions as long as your arm. Because on here you will get people who will offer answers, offer support and guidance. They will offer the virtual hand of friendship and all in a kind, caring and non judgmental way.  If you are here for a few days, weeks or months people will cheer you on and cheer you up. Now everyone will say don’t think about it. And you might shout easy for you to do I’m the one waiting. But there will possibly be a lot of waiting time for results and tests in the coming weeks. So find a good way to deal or cope with it. Some people post daily. Others wait. Some fill their days with work or good things. Some post all night see The Awake thread by tapping on the discussion tab. As I am on my iPad I can’t put links which would help. Apologies. Maybe another Champ can if needed But above all keep posting. Stay on reputable sites. Share your concerns with a loved one or a friend.  We will be here when you need support Be gentle with yourself Take care Leolady

Posts.Content: Trapin1 Yes and no. Yes letrozole can certainly cut back the desire for affection, emotions can be depressed and sexual desire certainly can be affected. There has been a lot of discussion of creams to use for vaginal dryness. Estriol and Sylk being mentioned. But if I am being totally honest with you - and I don't know you - all I have to go on is this post. I am thinking Letrozole is just a part of the jigsaw of your life at present. The other parts are quite defining moments in our lives. Surviving cancer, work changes, family changes. Just one of those could send anyone of us over the edge. The mending of our emotional and mental health is not a priority for the medics and I just wish it was. So we need to find ways to mend for ourselves. If that for you means tablets then why not? If it is for the coming days your lifebelt then so be it. If one counsellor didn't hit the mark there are others you can access. Seek out places where you can meet with other people who have survived BC or other cancers. Maggies Centres and Breast Cancer Care have courses to attend. Macmillan centre near me does relaxation drop in sessions. I so find 1 hr to myself good. I opened my eyes after the first session to find I was crying and to think I thought I had got BC licked. On a personal and professional note (others may not see or acknowledge this) OMG teaching is a draining profession. 38 years I did. Enjoy the retirement. I loved every day as every day was different, but that also meant some days sucked the life out of you. Yes, everyone else I know those committed to other jobs may well feel the same too. But I am just saying as one professional to another. Do keep posting as here is also an amazing source of support as you may know Have you read this article too? LINK Take care lovely lady think of all the lives you have made a difference to and now make a difference to yours Leolady56

Posts.Content: taralou  Bleeping heck that's one hell of a week and SE issues. But .... I think you need to be very careful with the reaction on your skin. Do you have a vaseline to create a barrier against infection creeping in. As we all know our immune system is compromised during chemo and the very last thing we all need is an added infection creeping in through cuts and abrasions. Gloves might help especially if you are in the kitchen Did a medic see the skin issues? If not, to be perfectly honest I would give the Triage people a call. Possibly need a steroid / hydrochortisone type cream - but would need a prescription and diagnosis for that. Hope you have a triage number They are there to be of help and no question is too silly - only if it is left too late Leolady56 - good luck lovely

Posts.Title: BC Mentally Not Coping / Help / Advice

Posts.Content: Hallam001 Good afternoon and a sad but warm welcome to the group. On here we can give advice and support through experience not necessarily as medics I have not experienced exactly what your wife has, but wanted to add a few thoughts in as to what needs looking at before Monday. Always heat in wounds or areas such as you describe after an operation. By comparing the 2 breasts and the heat found in the same area. Also checking her temperature in case of infection. See if it spreads or fills with fluid.If any of these are present then 111 call or a call to out of hours GP service (if your surgery has this).  My experience was an infection which required antibiotics after my first operation. That I discovered due to excessive heat and redness. Avoiding any clothing that could be irritating the area. Linen or cotton, loose tops.Removing the bra. Aloe Vera that has been in the fridge can be very cooling and gently dabbed onto the area to relieve itching. Aloe vera easily available in many shops I hope my simple ideas may be of help to your wife. I am sure other people may have better answers Take care both of you.  Leolady56 aka Lindsay

Posts.Title: Generally bloated and abdominal pains

Posts.Content: Roundhouse1  A warm welcome to the site but equally so sorry you have needed to find us. And more importantly that your mom has been diagnosed with breast cancer and is finding it all overwhelming  I am 62. I was diagnosed 11 months ago and I am still here. If I think about how breast cancer was dealt with in the past and think about women I knew who were diagnosed their life was quite short. But medicine and the battle against cancer has moved a million miles from then. Maybe your mom is thinking of the past and is unaware of what is available now to battle and win this. Or maybe she is ‘overwhelmed ‘ You could mention this all to her breast cancer nurse who can advise you and her how to deal with it all. The team supporting your mom might find it useful to know that they are going to have to help her battle the physical, emotional and mental sides of breast cancer. You can all phone the helpline on here 0808 808 00 00. Advice and guidance will be given in a non judgemental way. Don’t forget the GP too they are great, well mine is. They can signpost you to help Feel free to tap on my name and read my story to your mom. It’s not a straight forward one and does not include a mastectomy but I am here. I had - past tense - HER2 +++ and I have 3 weekly Herceptin plus Letrozole. There is no road map, manual or dvd given when we discover we have breast cancer. There is no one reaction that is right or wrong . There will be a host of emotions running through each and everyone of you throughout this and again not one is right or wrong. They just are.  There is Family and Friends part of the site and a Carers part if you look in Groups section. There you will find support too. Sorry I am on my iPhone so I can’t link you to them. When I get to my laptop I’ll post stories of survival as well if you think they will help her to read or listen to No doubt others are writing as I do with good advice  It is staring over the precipice of life for some but now medicine, docs and forums like this can pull us back from the edge. Survival rates are high 95% + Take care and be gentle with yourself too Leolady56

Posts.Content: Optimist  I wish, as everyone else who has posted, that I had a simple and easy answer. A cream, a tablet, a course or a nudge of the elbow. But no those are not the answers. Imagine how wealthy someone would be if it was so easy. There are a wealth of experiences to go through both during and after BC. It is probably akin to bereavement for some and total euphoria for others. What I have done is added a few links where you may find some support. Link The following is a group  Link I know that you post on several thread so hope the support you may find here very useful. As Granny59 has said you are a survivor and survive the next stage you will Maggie's BC may have answers too  Link And several years ago I did work with a telephone counsellor who helped me no end. I use some of her phrases when chatting on here. Not least her 'look after the inner child' one. Could that be an answer for you too? Are you a member of a trade union they can offer free support - that's how I got mine. Sending you hugs and special thoughts. The last lot was doable for you and so the next lot of *** will be too. Plus you have all the lovely women and men here cheering you on. Take care and be gentle. One day at a time  Leolady xxxx

Posts.Title: Down day

Posts.Content: Mountainhiker Good morning from the UK. And sorry you find yourself here and that your mom has been through this. You say as your final comment 'cancer is such a whirlwind'and that is so so true.It would seem you have been swept up into and that you are at a complete loss to explain away the cruelty and uncertainty that it brings to everyone I think possibly the need to be private about health issues,especially those related to breast and womb cancer,can be a generational 'thing'. Also many people do not want the cancer to define them or for others to change their attitudes towards them. Nor do they want their children to necessarily become their carers orput their lives on hold. As to how long you have got left with your mother???? How long is that piece of string?? That is rather cruel answer, but any day of the week we could fall foul of a reckless driver or pick up a bug that takes away our life.You say that her cancer is a slow growing cancer and no mets on vital organs. All good signs It is time to make the very best memories you can and surround her with love. In the incurable group on the site, people are there 5/6 years on from diagnosis. And as you science gallops on and new meds appear with regularity I haven't necessarily answered your question,but truly can the medics? The people posting here are (like me) living with or surviving cancer.We do have an Ask an Expert section where you may get a fuller medical answer. We have many groups here that you may find very helpful Friends and Family HER2+ information from the site I wish your mother a gentle way through the treatment and for you the strength to be a loving son May your gods be with Leolady56

Good luck There are quite a few chats here regarding the brands, if you want to read more just put Letrozole in the search bar by new discussion Leolady56
Posts.Title: Clenmark Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Sorry diving in on your chat but ........ Oestrogen is produced by the adrenal glands and in fatty tissue. Hence why women post menopausal are encouraged to keep to a good BMI. Mmmm I missed that lesson until too late. Obviously I am still at the ripe old age of 61 and  producing oestrogen. I am not saying this the professionals are. Decisions regarding Tamoxifen, Letrozole etc etc will be based on HER status of your cancer, your age, pre and post menopausal. Plus a lot more factors depending on your general health.  But as the lovely wombat.23 has said we only hear of different side effects when they happen. Until now I rarely looked at the info in my meds package. Now I'm a positive demon and read every last word. Well all take care and e gentle with yourselves, there is no one perfect answer for everyone but there is one hopefully for you Leolady

Posts.Title: Possible node

Posts.Content: AmyKan2018 A very sad but warm welcome, as you say, to a group we did not know existed. This has certainly been a tough year for your family. The answers to your questions may seem quite vague but truth to tell so far you mention Stage 3 BC but there are many other pathology elements that will help the doctors decide on the way forward for treatment. Sometimes chemo is used to shrink a tumour first and for others it is used to ensure no stray cancer cells have escaped into the rest of the body. Pathology of the tumour will come from biopsies which you have not mentioned as yet. Some people take oral medication for 5-10 years,depending on the type of cnacer, which have side effects but save lives. I am on called Letrozole for 5-10 yrs  The pros and cons of private hospitals versus NHS is one that challenges many. The bottom line is the surgeons are often the same, not all hospitals private or NHS have the same equipment. I have heard of costs ranging from£10-15,000. A large sum One place where you will certainly get good advice is the helpline 0808 808 00 00. They are open until 8pm. They will point you in the right direction and may have advice about where your mother lives Wishing you all a gentle way through this Gentle hugs and positive thoughts Leolady56
Posts.Title: BC stage 3B - private treatment

Posts.Content: Kacang  and GBear Due to lots of bleeping mess ups with first onco I am now on my 2nd onco. I like to get my moneys worth from the NHS!!! All I have had so far is 2 telephone chats with onco 2. My appointment is 13th and I was going to ask about Port as reading so much about  PICC and infections (sorry those who have them) So I will be almost 90 days post op when I start as NICE guidelines suggest no more than 31 there is a little bit of formal complaining from my side Pax is the first part, Herceptin as well then 20x Rads to follow. Onco said he will stop after 8 Pax if needed as I have had issues with my heart. Had rheumatic fever as a child, slightly enlarged heart, pericarditis in 2016 and high BP. Wooooo hooooooo. Today is Pneumococcal injection. Plus an echocardiogram and ECG next week. (blimey my spelling has improved all these words testing me). So could you all please keep paying your taxes as I don't want them to run out of money. I am off to have my injection after all the babies at 12 today. Made me giggle Well everyone on here I have a very weird sense of humour so be warned when I officially join the group. Not intended ever to upset just my pressure valve release. God bless to all those being zapped today, to those on a bad day. To those on a good day make it count. Leolady56 - ducking and diving PS Oh have a caravan to clean out! Mmmmmmm

Posts.Content: Ladies apologies 1. This is a copy and paste from The OP Thread 2. My mushy brain cannot cope with individual replies now. I will try tomoorw My POOP: I woke this morning to tomato coloured and swollen skin on face, neck and arms and hands . So off for the Herceptin Jab. But noooooo we need to look at the tomato issue first. Luckily Onco man - nice onco man - was in residence. Oh that's a reaction to chemo!  So I had some anithistamines with me and we decided to take those one a day until next chemo. But if I react again it's back to the drawing board.  No reactions yet to Herceptin But 9-3.30 in the unit.  My daughter was great  Bit miffed. Bit confused. Bit WTF. Bit not again for those who have seen me go through various reactions after my ops. At least they are visible and obvious to the medics So how was you poop today. Oh yes I need to get Hemocane as well. Everything is just piling up and I've only done 2 bleeping days. This could be a War and Peace or Forsythe Saga read though LL and her chemo. Need a natty title Leolady56

Posts.Content: Weeblemum and those of you still awake There was once upon a time a song 'My word you do look queer' And not meant in any other way than ill. Stanley Holloway an old music hall act Gone for a short hair style. And my lovely hairdresser will buzz cut when I need it done. Before or after opening hours, God bless him. Not convinced about wigs. But lots of lovely scarf head gear out there. Bamboo ones for keeping the head cool. That's my addition to the chat. Echo done quick visit. 30 mins and a lovely lady who told me I was a good girl So .... looks like all aboard for me as apparently a good heart considering my age!!!!! Made up for the Onco saying I was obese. Taking the good  Leolady56
